div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p:
THE following play was written above three years ago, and was soon after shewn to some of the principal performers of both houses. It took its rise from Miss EL
LIOT'S being advised to revive The Country Wife for her benefit the first season of her engagement at Covent-Garden theatre. That play, upon a review of it, appeared inad
missible on account of the obscenity which discolours the whole. The author, or rather the compiler of the en
suing scenes, undertook to alter WYCHERLEY's play for Miss ELLIOT against the following winter; but hearing, in the mean time, that Mr. BICKERSTAFF had employed himself upon one of WYCHERLEY's pieces, he made it his business to see that gentleman, lest this writer should inter
fere with a plan already pre-occupied. He found that the PLAIN DEALER had been Mr. BICKERSTAFF's object, and that there was no danger of clashing with the scheme of any other author. Upon a closer examination, therefore, of The Country Wife, it was thought proper to desert it in
tirely, and to resort to MOLIERE, the original master whom WYCHERLEY copied. The celebrated comedy of L'Ecole de Femmes appeared too thin of business, consisting mostly in narrative. To supply that deficiency the design occurred of making MOLIERE himself supply the requisite materials; and for this purpose L'ETOURDIE and L'Ecole DE MARIS were called in as auxiliaries. Upon this idea the play was soon finished, and it consists of characters, situations, and business, from those three plays, interwoven into one fable, with as much skill as a little leisure in the summer time would permit. With the professed design of condensing what appeared to be the best of three performances into one play, it was deemed unnecessary to suppress any one scene of true nature, merely because the author of High Life below Stairs, and some other English writers, might occasionally be tracked in the snow of Moliere.

The play, when finished, was given to Miss ELLIOT, and it so happened, that she had no opportunity of producing it till this season. When in September last, her bargain both for herself and the play was in agitation with Mr. BEARD, the author of these sheets was astonished to hear that The Country Girl was actually in rehearsal at Drury Lane, and that the parts had been given out in the summer, nay, as fast as they were written. This, it must not be dissembled, looked like a design of forestalling the market; especially as it was understood, that Miss ELLIOT and the SCHOOL FOR GUARDIANS, had been offered the spring before to the ma
nager of Drury Lane, upon his own terms. A remonstrance was immediately made to Mr. GARRICK, purporting that he, who had long been a manager of a successful theatre, was going to enter into a competition with a young actress for the pro
fits of a play. A meeting ensued, where a gentleman of the first character for probity and genius, was so obliging as to be the arbitrator. Mr. GARRICK there protesting, that he never heard of Miss ELLIOT's play till within a few days; it was thereupon determined, that it was, in that case, an accidental clashing, but that a design of forestalling would have been illiberal and unhandsome. This last point of ho
nour Mr. GARRICK seemed to learn upon this occasion.

Both parties were, in consequence, left to pursue their own interests. And now the present writer will dismiss THE SCHOOL FOR GUARDIANS, after saying, that he com
posed it with the most disinterested principle; and that, if it prove in any degree conducive to the service of a young actress, or the public entertainment, he has all the reward he ever proposed to himself.

N. B. An entire scene in the second act, page 30. has been omitted since the first representation, and would have been discarded from this edition, but that the greatest part of the play was printed, before it was acted.

sp.l: MAY I intrude upon your patience for a minute?
Ladies and gentlemen, before the opening of the play,
Just to excuse an accident, which, I hope has no mischief in it,
I fain, if you'll permit, a word or two would say.
I hope you'll not be angry; but we've got no prologue for to night;
And so I thought it was best to come and tell ye all the truth downright.
I went to Mr. Poet, and I spoke to him all I could,
But he said he had not leisure, tho' I know it's in his power if he would.
"A prologue, ma'am," says he!—"Yes, Sir, a prologue if you please."
And then I did so entreat the man, and beg, and pray, and teaze.
I told him, "You know, Sir, what a miserable plight we all are in,
To frown upon the performers, when pit, box, and gallery begin;
Whu—go the catcalls—dub—dub—dub—each dreadful critick's stick
Prólog'— throw him over—won't ye ha some orange chips—Prólôgué—Cries o' London—Musick!"
All this and more I said, but he, determin'd still,
In formal fustian thus declar'd his will.
"Oft have I tried"[seems puzzled]—something about his stile,
And how he felt the Town's indulgent smile.
"Were I again to try my scanty vein,
I'd beg protection for the feeble strain.
But then to sue—he paus'd and rubb'd his head—
To sue—when fam'd MOLIERE the stage doth tread,
Were to prophane the manes of the dead.
MOLIERE, of old, and still with rapture seen,
Was legislator of the comic scene.
To bid his SIMPLE GIRL assert the stage,
And if she pleases, strive to mend the age,
This was my motive;—this my only aim;
Heedless of gain!—no candidate for fame!
An audience will weigh all in equal scales,
For justice, and not party, there prevails."
Thus spoke Mr.Poet, and then with long steps march'd away;
And now I am left alone to apologize for offering you this night's play.
We'll strive to make you laugh, if our aim be not perverted;
Pray, how d'ye find yourselves?—Are ye in good humour, and willing to be diverted?
If you approve,
The Rostiad Scribbler then no more I'll dread,
Who points his malice at a woman's head!
Who drop by drop his venom doth distil,
While MOTHER-DULLNESS guides the hireling's quill.
Lull'd in her lap, strange wonders he descries,
And TERENCE seems—a Frenchman to his eyes!
From thence he issues soul decrees on plays,
Adorns with scandal, and lampoons with praise.
One smile from you defeats the sland'rer's aim;
His calumny, like your APPLAUSE, is fame.
From your applause our mimic glories rise;
In pleasing you my whole ambition lies.

lg.l: LAdies, your servant—Servant, gentlemen all—
The same good folks to you—both great and small.
Here's MARY ANN again:—but that an't fair,
To jeer a simple girl you might forbear.
Who knows, since married,—tho' you laugh and gaze,
But MARY ANN may learn your London ways?
May ape your fashions, since you've shewn her how,
And drop the mask at once—as I do now.
Thus you behold,—whatever the condition,
To new extremes how easy the transition.
'Tis so thro'life:—to town from country fairs
The clown comes up, and gapes, and laughs, and stares!
Give him a liv'ry,—whims unknown before!
He learns his master's follies to do o'er;
He drinks,— illegible u illegible s coxcomb, and betts five to four.
Pray, may I, ladies, touch your modish life,
And shew good sense and fashion there at strife?
"Oh! do Miss Elliot, says a prude with spite,
Pull'em to pieces; bring their faults to light;
Pulling to pieces is my dear delight."
Why then each fair one seems a diff'rent creature
From what she's meant, and travesties her nature.
Proud of defects, FLIRTILLA swims along,
Politely weak, and elegantly wrong.
Thro' the gay round of time her only care
To fix the patch, and guide a straggling hair.
Lady CAMILLA, form'd to seize the rein,
To rival John, and smack along the plain;
In London sickens with dissembled airs,
And "help me—help me up these odious stairs."
Nature's best gifts we all with pride disclaim;
We lisp, we totter, deaf, and blind, and lame.
The tongue indeed we women ne'er confine;
—Scandal's too dear a pleasure to resign.
Scandal, and cards, tea, mirth, and spleen, a ball,
Comus!—the monkey too!—and there's the life of'all.
A life of whim!—till from she faded eye,
And wither'd form, the trembling graces fly.
There's a true picture!—how do ye like it, ladies?
How is the light? and how do ye think the shade is?
A copy hence our simple girl may make;
Unless she should this wiser counsel take,
Be rul'd by reason for your beauty's sake.
Reason still gives to radiant eyes their grace,
Warren's imperial milk—for ev'ry face.
Beauty, ye fair, may forge the lover's chain;
But the mind's charms your empire must maintain.

body.head: THE School for Guardians, A COMEDY.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: BUT I won't be told; I won't reason about it; I won't be answered; I won't hear a word.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I have done, Sir—you have proved it to demonstration, by the same sort of logick that was used by one of the wits of Charles the lld's. time to his dog, when he was too lazy to beat him, "I wish you well married, and settled in the country"—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p:
There again now; don't enrage me; I have some whimsical humours about me, that let me tell you, Sir—and I can be very peremptory, if I please—What? when my neighbour Strickland and I have agreed the matter!—a young lady with a fair fortune in hand, and seven hundred a year in expect
ancy, as pretty a reversion as any in Hampshire!— and am I now to be told, "She does not suit my taste,—she is not handsome?" and so I am to be
wasting my breath with you, about a complection, a nose, and a lip!—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: If you would but leave those matters to me, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: But I tell you no; I won't leave those matters to you—Beauty is the last thing I desire to see in my family—Your mother, peace be to her, was as ugly a woman as you shall see in a summer's day; and what do you think I married her for?— for your good, Sir—for the good of my children—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: And pray, Sir, which of ye does this side-box face of mine take after?

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: You shall take nothing after me, that you may depend upon, unless you prove obedient to my will and pleasure.—I'll not leave you a foot of land—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I hope you'll live to enjoy it yourself, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: I'll give my fortune to found a new college, where it is not wanted—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I hope you'll live to enjoy it yourself, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: I'll cut you off with a shilling to buy you an halter—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I hope you'll live to enjoy it yourself, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: I hope I shall, tho' you say it with a sort of a dry look between just and earnest—But don't talk to me of beauty again; I never knew any good come of it; beauty is like fine fruit, only fit to draw a parcel of flies about it—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: And so I must set my teeth on edge with crab-tree apples—But where would be the harm, Sir, if purely for the good of my family, I were to marry a lady of some share of beauty, only just to cross the strain a little, and settle a shape and a feature upon the issue of our marriage?

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p:
Settle your wife's fortune upon 'em—Look ye, Sir;—my purse strings will never open,—
not a shilling of my money shall you touch, till you pay your respects to Miss Strickland—now you know my resolution—What a graceless look there is! ruin yourself if you will—follow your own courses, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
Your most obedient very humble ser
vant, Sir,—you may depend that—I shall chuse for myself—Brisk! why don't you answer, sirrah!—Why Brisk!—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
We have been pretty handsomely lec
tured here this morning, Brisk!—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p:
Yes, Sir, we have had wherewithal to edify by—I suppose, we shall lie at Tom Tilbury's at Bag
shot to-night, Sir—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Tom Tilbury's, Sir—only just to break the neck of our journey, for I suppose now, you'll drop all thoughts of this other lady—I forget her name—Ay! miss Mary Ann Richley—She has no chance now, I reckon, Sir—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
Why, you senseless numskull!—as sure as I am Charles Brumpton, Esq she shall be Mrs. Brumpton; and upon the death of my very good fa
ther, she'll be a baronet's lady, that's all—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p:
And yet there is some truth in what Sir Theodore says—Beauty is but a frail perishable sort of a commodity; and if you are disinherited for it, the lady's charms will not pay your poor servant, Brisk, his board-wages; a feature, or a smile can't go to market; a pawn-broker will lend nothing upon the tip of an ear: though indeed she may mortgage her person; but that I take it will be for her own advan
tage; we shall get nothing but a comely pair of horns by it, Sir, with submission—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Why you talk a frothy kind of nothing at a tolerable rate, Brisk—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: I have shewn you one side of the medal, now behold the reverse, Sir—When you marry an ugly woman, there is no great pleasure in beholding her, and to be sure when you look at her, you'll be apt to murmur to yourself—for all purposes of joy one may cut as desirable an object out of an old tapestry-hanging—but then the woman has some valuable parchments, such as leases, bonds, and mortgages; and I, Sir, shall live in tolerable plight with you, which to so good a master—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
Leave prating, sirrah, and do as I or
dered you—put on your farmer's dress, go directly to the object I adore—let her know you are come from her guardian in the country, and have his or
ders to take her home under your care—convey her safe to my arms, and I shall reward you—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: But, Sir—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: No arguing with me—about it streight—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: You know how many blanketings and blows I have suffered in your service, Sir—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Sirrah, no words—go and see who's at the door—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: You have marred many an excellent plot of mine, Sir—you know you cannot help meddling, when I undertake a scheme—If you'll promise me, Sir, not to—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Will you see who's at the door?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: I am gone, Sir—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—I shall most certainly carry her off—How Sir Theodore will be astonished when he finds she is an heiress!—Ha! ha!—it is the pleasantest adventure—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Brumpton, good morrow!—always in spirits, I see.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
My dear Belford, nothing depresses my spirits—though you thought they were too high last night, and were for letting me a little blood. Death!
man, you make nothing of displaying an ell of sword
blade in defence of your mistress's top-knot.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Why you know I love too tenderly to bear the test of raillery—it is the infirmity of my temper; why would you put me to it?—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: And you that know my turn of mind, why would you be angry with me?—I am happily a follower of the laughing philosopher—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
Po! prithee, man, don't be such a cox
comb.—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Prithee, don't you be so morose, so sour, so discontented a spirit—But if in your phrase I am a coxcomb, with all my heart, i'faith: but take this along with you—what you mean as a term of reproach, I receive as a compliment to the materials nature has been pleased to compound in this happy frame of mine—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Po! Po! running on at the old rate—If self-applause be philosophy, you have a comfortable share.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I have, Sir, and while my happiness is preserved by it, keep you the gravity and good sense, that make you too refined to be pleased, too wise to be merry, and too knowing to be contented.—I am in a fair way to be successful, without any trouble at all;—you are likely to be most scurvily disappointed after a world of pains—An humble bow, which my dancing-master taught me, while I laughed at him, a fashionable coat, for which, if my taylor is ever paid he will laugh at me,—an intriguing snuff-box,— and an apt valet de chambre, all these make love for me, and—.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
And you assume the merit of the con
quest—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
Oh! yes, when the trouble is over, I take the reward.—Did you ever know a general officer, who, when the horse and the foot, and the right and left wing have carried the day for him, did not claim to himself both the honour and the booty?
But you make a toil of a pleasure—love, which to me is a scene of delight, to you is a drudgery; your temper grows as sour, as a prude's when the sermon is long; and as hot as a Welshman's, if you laugh at his pedigree; or a professed sharper's, if you doubt his honour, after he has cogged the dice, and picked your pocket of your money.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
Why I own I am piqued and naturally. If any friend of mine, out of mere spleen, speak de
tractingly of the person I admire: it were base infi
delity in love not to defend her, when she is dispa
raged—my every thought is dedicated to her.—Absent I see her, hear her, and my imagination gloats for ever on her charms.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
And you are so easily alarmed, that little difficulties are the Alps and Pireneans in your way—Now my faith in these matters removes mountains—But indeed in all things we are opposite characters—If a tradesman brings you in a bill and presses for payment, 'Sdeath! does the scoundrel doubt my honour? does he mean to affront me?—Now I, when my father suffered me to be arrested, went cheerfully into con
finement, and diverted myself for three weeks together with the bum-bailiff's character—In the business of our softer passions, the same humour pursues us—you write studied letters to your Dulcinea, I am written to;—you sigh, I sing;—you fret I am gay;—you, upon a disappointment, Furies, death, and rage—there is no enduring this—life is grown a burden—damnation! I burst into a laugh, and what a whimsical world we live in—ha! ha!—But come, I will hear your melancholy story,—Well, the old dragon I suppose watches the Hesperian fruit.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
He does, Sir—he keeps her locked up as a miler does his gold, not to be made use of till his death, and then to fall into hands that won't know the value of it—Its love's last shift with me; she is inaccessible, and her guardian, old Lovibond, pro
poses to marry her himself.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: And so, like the tyrant of old, intends to tack a living and dead body together.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Even so—my dear Brumpton, there should be an act of parliament to hinder these old fellows from stopping the propagation of the species.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
You are too hard upon 'em—they are seldom guilty of that mischief;—I have known 'em have twins at a birth; that is, when some such cox
comb as myself gives them a helping hand;—and then the old fellow cocks his hat upon it, and totters about so vigorously, wondering how the babes resem
ble him in every particular; whilst the mother knows, that she followed the example of the Grecian painter, and took a feature from every one of her acquaint
ance.—If he prevents your marrying her, take your revenge that way.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
Prophanation!—her virtue, Sir—besides the world could never repair the loss—her heart I am sure is mine—I used to visit there—but now no admittance; an evidence on the crown side in a mes
senger's hands is not better secured.

sp.speaker: Brompton.
sp.p:
Now my business goes on without any trouble or difficulty. My old dragon is in the coun
try, and has left his fair ward, the sweetest girl, my dear Belford.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
You described her yesterday but few re
moves from a downright idiot.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
Pardon me—she is simple indeed—But such a simplicity!—It just serves to shew that in
justice has been done her in her education, but in her every turn she gives such tokens of sensibility!—She has beauty without knowing it;—certain wild graces, rather than accomplishments, and talents instead of sense.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Po! Po!—a mere rustic beauty.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
There now, derogating from her merit, and yet I am calm!—the truth is she has been brought up in the country, and wickedly kept in ignorance,
that she might fall an easy prey to her guardian—But I have raised a spirit in her.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: And how the devil did you gain access to her?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I was going to tell you—Old Nestor's out of town, and has left her in the care of the two veriest simpletons that ever whistled for want of thought at a country fair—But gold, Sir, gold, that speaks all languages, and adapts itself to all capacities, has pleaded most eloquently for me—But, come, I positively must leave you.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Nay, if it must be so—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: My dear Belford, Cupid direct your arrows—
sp.l: I see her every day, and all the day,
And every day is still but as the first,
So eager am I still to see her more.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: And but this moment returned, Mr. Oldcastle!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Just this moment stepped out of the machine—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Well! and now I suppose you have prudently laid aside all thoughts of matrimony.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
Ha! you are a comical man, brother Lo
vibond,—I have taken my measures; to-morrow makes me a bridegroom, and my fair ward Miss Mary Ann, a bride—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: And a little time will make you—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Happy—tho', by that significant look, you have your doubts.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I have Sir—I have a shrewd guess that—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Then you'll be out in your guess—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I wish your horns a'n't out first—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Well said, and without any apprehension for yourself; you are still determined to marry Mary Ann's sister Harriet I suppose.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: That's quite another business; what I do, is no rule for your actions—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
It is as I ever said—each man is still look
ing at the hump upon his neighbour's back, but never thinks of casting an eye over his own shoulder—I warrant me now you, in your grand climacteric, will tell me I am old—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Full ten years before me in the race of life—besides, you are an old batchelor;—a stranger to the ways of wedlock—I am enured to the service—your sister, Mr. Oldcastle, could have told you what a desperate good husband I was—But, lack a day!— you begin late—mercy on your forehead, say I, mercy on your forehead!—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Ha! ha! how blind some people are when they have taken a thing in their heads!—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Well! well! laugh on—but you that have been for ever a censor of your neighbours, for ever fleering and jibing at the married life—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
And a pleasant topic it is!—Why matri
mony affords a little comedy in every family one knows—But the education I have given Mary Ann—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Is the worst in the world—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
The very best!—I have trained her up in plain simplicity—woman's wit teems with contriv
ances to disgrace her husband—yet you would educate Harriet in this profligate town!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ay, and I have taught her to know right from wrong.—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Right from wrong! you have ruined the girl—have not you indulged her in every whimsy this fertile town affords?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I have shewn her the world—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Have not you carried her to plays?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: To see folly ridiculed—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: To profligate comedies?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: The stage is the school of virtue—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: The school of sin and impudence!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
Where vice undergoes the lash of sa
tire—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
Where vice is made alluring, provok
ing—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Where young ladies may learn—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: The use of dark-closets, back-stairs, and ladders of rope.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Where they may learn to put on the veil of modesty.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: To put on the breeches, and escape from their guardians!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Where they are taught to respect grey-headed authority!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
To make a cuckold of authority!—I know the ways of 'em all!—their cards, routs, operas, Soho-assemblies, all contrivances to excite cu
riosity, kindle desire, prompt inclination, and send 'em all dancing a jig to destruction.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Common-place invective!—Harriet will know how to avoid—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: She will know how to deceive you—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: She will have too much honour —

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: She will have too much wit—now Mary Ann has no wild notions, and of course no dangerous curiosity.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Her curiosity is to come—she'll fall a prey to the first powdered coxcomb that bows to her—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Her simplicity will preserve her—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
But when the serpents of this town be
gin to whisper in her ear—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
They'll have no opportunity—She is snug in a little box of an house, which I have taken in the name of Mr. Biddulph. I have another lodging in my own name, where I do business.—Nobody will see her; and when the nine day's wonder is over,
I shall pack off to the country, and so escape from impertinence.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
Well! well!—I can't but laugh at your system of education! ha! ha!—Marry her if you will;—and then on account of your age and infirmi
ties, you may do the business of your office by de
puty—Ha! ha! a plan of simplicity!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Brother Lovibond, a good day to you—I wish you success—Ha! ha! a town-education for a young girl!—
Ha! ha! poor man tottering to bed to a young wife—I'll go home to my own Harriet—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: 'Sdeath and confusion! my dull brain can devise nothing—hey! is not that old Argus Centoculi with all his eyes out?—Mr. Lovibond,—a sight of you—what have you been out of town?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: No, the builders are carrying the town out of town I think, and so, a body need not move out of London for country air—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: How charmingly you look!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: What you call a green old age—I am not like the young rakes about this town, who decay in their prime, and are fourscore at five and twenty.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
Ay! you have lived upon the interest of your constitution, and have not out-run the princi
pal—I have had the honour of knocking at your door several times—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I know it—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: But no body at home—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I know that too—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I want to lose a little more money to you at back-gammon—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I have left it off—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Well! well! I'll come and eat a bit of mutton with you—How stand you for to-day?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: What an hurry he is in? [aside] I have an unlucky engagement—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Well! I'll take a morsel of supper—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Well pushed! [aside.] I have left off suppers—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: So best—I'll be with you at breakfast in the morning—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
I have taken to breakfasting at the coffee-house—One meets with very sensible people at the coffee-house, and hears men praised for being out of place, and abused for being in place,—and a huge deal of news, that's very entertaining in the morning; and all a damned lie in the evening.—Your ser
vant—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: But the fair Miss Harriet—how does she do?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: There he has touched the right string at last [aside] I'll let her know how kind you are.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Nay, don't fly so soon—I am to give you joy, I hear—you are to make Miss Harriet happy, I understand.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Oh! no; they talk at random—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Yes, yes; come, you have taught her all her accomplishments, and are now to teach her the art of love—ha! ha! Mr. Lovibond—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I profess no such thing.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
Yes, yes, come—shall I dance at your wedding—you'll trust her with me in a country dance, and see that lovely bosom heave in sweet dis
order, and rise as if it wooed your hand to touch it, e'er it fails again—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—you talk loosely—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
Then when musick wakens every gentler passion, and the sprightly romping has called forth all her bloom; then you'll lead her off, consenting trem
bling, doubting, blushing—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—come, I'll go and dine with you—"The world must be peopled, you know"— Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Well! well! let him be obstinate, if he will—I must step, and see how Mary Ann has fared these ten days, since I have been in the country.—Let me see, what's o'clock?—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: How her old gaoler will look when he returns to town, and finds she has broke prison! I shall be deemed the very Machiavel of intrigue!—Hey! is not that Mr. Oldcastle?—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Mr. Brumpton!—I rejoice to see you—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
My dear friend, you are come in the very crisis of my fate, in that dear extatic moment, when to the natural vivacity of a gay, giddy tem
per like mine, ten thousand circumstances conspire to lift me to the upper regions of delight, which, toge
ther with the felicity of encountering the only man in the world, that—I must take breath—I am faint with bliss—it is too much—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Ay! your fever is pretty high, I see—recover your senses a little—and tell me at your leisure what is this mighty business—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
Oh! business of such a nature—the Gods are now in council upon it,—I expect Mercury every moment in the shape of my man Brisk, to let me know that the nectared sweets that dwell upon the lips of a certain lady are intended for a wild un
thinking coxcomb, as the world is pleased to call me—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
To be sure—you are in request among the ladies, no doubt—Now will he lie like an at
torney's clerk [aside] You are going to help some worthy gentleman to an heir to his estate, I warrant me—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I have done some service in that way; but the truth is, I am now going to help my father to a grandson.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Going to be married!—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
This day may perhaps crown my joys—some certain fumblers at this end of the town, who were a little alarmed at the proportions of this leg, intend to light their windows upon it; the court of aldermen are preparing all demonstrations of joy; and their unhappy wives are going into deep mourn
ing upon the occasion!—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: The same confident fop he ever was! well, and my friend Sir Theodore, what says he to all this?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
You know his way; the same old crab
ed humour—he has made a match for me elsewhere with one that—I would not deny the lady her merit—she preserves pickles well, and is a very notable keeper of accounts—the woman will do very well of a long winter's evening to say, Bless you when you sneeze—but—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: She has a fortune, I presume—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Does not want acres—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: And you prefer one without any

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: You mistake me! she's an heiress; it is not clear that she is of age, but as soon as she comes to years of discretion—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Then she may play the fool as fast as she will—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: By chusing me, you think, she will give a specimen of her folly.—Ha! ha! I have passed many hours with her of late; she is beautiful as an angel—Now, my dear Sir, you can do me the most essential service—you have great influence over Sir Theodore,—I dare not break this matter to him myself, but a word from you—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: And has she really an estate?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: A very fine one;—a large number of acres, and a coal-pit upon one of the manors—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I profess I like your taste—ha! ha! The coal-pit whitens her skin, and she may hereafter wear a few of her own acres in each ear—I will see my old friend about this, and will positively promote your welfare.—He shall agreee to it, and—But how did you bring this about, pray?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: An old way that I have—I came, saw, and conquered—I saw her at her window—such blooming sweetness! Her eyes were through my heart at once—love inspired me with due courage—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: That was right—a bold stroke for a wife—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
I drank tea with her the very next even
ing—I must indeed admit, that her understanding is not the most accomplished—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: So best—never marry a wit—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
She is at present rather in a state of igno
rance; but from those blue eyes she occasionally darts such glances, as bespeak a mind susceptible of the highest refinement.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Where does she live?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: In the very next street—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: What that street there?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Yes, that—under the care of the verriest muck-worm—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: He means me, I fear [aside.] and her name, pray—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Miss Mary Ann Richley—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Wounds! what a discovery here is!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
Her guardian's name is Biddulph—per
haps you may know him—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: No, not I—the young rake-hell!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
He means to abuse his trust, and con
fine youth and beauty within the arms of age and ugliness.—There's an old rogue for you!—Does not he deserve to be hanged?

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: What a young villain!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I beg your pardon—I did not hear—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
I am seized with an ugly fit of cough
ing— [coughs.] But you should consider—the mar
riage-act is very strict, and requires the consent of prudent people—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
Po! that's nothing—abuse Scotland as they will, it enables us to evade the laws of Eng
land.—My dear Mr. Oldcastle, you have promised me you'll speak to my father—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
Ay! I'll keep my word—He shall cer
tainly know how you are going on—I'll do you that good turn, you may depend—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: My dear good friend, it is so lucky that I met with you—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I am heartily glad I met you, indeed—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Well now, adieu!—Oh! but I forgot to tell you—She'll be mine this very day.—Brisk, my fellow,—who is a footman of talents, is to go to her as a tenant from the country, come to town with old Biddulph's commands to carry her down with him in the fly.—She is so simple she will believe it; and the oafs about her will bite like gudgeons—and so—ha! ha!—I kindle into rapture;—I must fly to know the happy tidings—and so fare ye well—you'll speak to my father—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I'll do for you there—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: A million of thanks to you—Ha! ha! is not this a charming adventure?—Ha! ha!—Did you ever know so happy a rogue?

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
I never knew so abandoned a young profligate, nor so damned an adventure!—If the fellow is lurking about my doors, I'll swear a robbery against him—If I get sight of him, I'll de
scribe him from head to foot; and swear he stole a horse in Northamptonshire—I have not a moment to lose,—and then, my young madam, bag and baggage away into the country.

div.head: ACT II.
div.p: HO! ho! ye powers of laughter, you will shake me to pieces one day or other!—Poor Brisk!— What a jade's trick madam Fortune has play'd him!—He writes me here— [going to read.] All the poor devil's ill stars must have been combined against him!—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
Yes, all my ill stars are combined, sure enough!—Oh! Brumpton! I have seen her guardian, that superannuated iniquity! but he defeats my hap
piness, and crosses all my schemes.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: You were admirably employed, my dear Belford—Ha! ha!—"Cato's a proper person to entrust a love-tale with."

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: You mirth is unseasonable, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Nay, if you will run about like a great boy to catch old birds with chaff, when you ought to seize the young unfledged one in its nest; why the consequence will be, that, like a great blubbering boy, you'll come back with your finger in your eye, "I don't know what to do—I can't catch it—I can't—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! insulted thus—draw, Sir—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Not I, truly—I am otherwise disposed—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Defend yourself, or I'll dispose of you—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Well! kill me, if you will—I'll die laughing like Pierre in the tragedy—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Po! your meanness and your folly make you unworthy of my sword—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Ay! that's right—and now in due form, what has provoked you?

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! Sir, because your affairs are in a tolerable train, am I to be made your sport? Oh! you don't know what it is to be disappointed in the tenderest passion—

sp.speaker: Brumpton
sp.p:
But I am disappointed, and in the ten
derest passion too; and yet it was that very disap
pointment I was laughing at; and not my friend—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: And are your purposes crossed too?—My dear brother sufferer—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
Ay! now I am unfortunate—Oh! the human mind!—Yes, Sir, I am disappointed—Ha! ha!—Brisk is in a devil of a pickle! He went in dis
guise to carry off my little goddess for me—Some
body that resembles him has committed a robbery in Northamptonshire—They have charged Brisk, and he writes me here, that they have carried him before Mr. Carbuncle, the wine-merchant, who deals out bad law, and adulterate port, to all St. Anne's parish—Brisk will be chronicled in miserable elegy, clubbed by two poets upon a flock-bed in the Old Jewry;—the historians of Grub-street are already preparing "The Life and Conversation of Jeremy Brisk, who was born of honest parents"—Ha! ha! poor devil! I must go to his assistance—

sp.speaker: Mittimus.
sp.p: Here, bring the prisoner this way—A great pity, master Squeezum, that Mr. Carbuncle is not at home—This fellow will be carried to another shop, I fear—

sp.speaker: Squeezum.
sp.p:
No, no; that shan't be—I have found another justice to sit for him—a gentleman who has
been in the commission many years—He was going by in his chariot, but I stopped him—Here, bring in the prisoner—

div.stage: Enter Brisk, dressed as a country fellow.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p:
Nay, good christian people—gentlemen—neighbours—I never was in Northamptonshire in my life—I am a poor, harmless, innocent fellow—I al
ways had a mortal aversion to a cart—I never saw one in my days but it was better than a sermon to me—

div.stage: Enter Sir Theodore, with a Letter in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p:
Well! well! I am not fond of act
ing, but rather than justice should be at a stand—The fellow answers the description!—Sirrah, what can you say for yourself?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p:
Hi! hi! what shall I say?—your hum
ble servant, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Free and familiar!—mind what you say, this is a serious business—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Dear heart, Sir, does not your honour know me?—your son's faithful and honest servant, Brisk—

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Brisk!—what rogue's trick have you been playing, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Your honour knows, Sir, I have not been out of your house any time these six weeks past—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: And why in this disguise, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Nothing but a frolick, Sir—a mere freak of my young master's, Sir, and nothing more—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p:
Commit him for further examina
tion—Rascal, I will know the whole—make out a warrant—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Sir, Sir,—I—you shall hear it all—the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p:
Very well, and if you dare attempt to deceive—Clear the room, and leave us to our
selves [exeunt all the rest.] If you tell me a single falsehood—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Not a tittle, Sir—the fact is, Sir—my master is in love desperately with a young lady from the country—He says she is an heiress, Sir, but I own I don't believe it—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Go on—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: And, Sir, I was to go in this dress, and so to carry her off, and deliver her over to him—That's the short and the long of it, Sir, as I am a sinner.—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: And as you value your ears, this is the truth?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Oh! upon honour, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Hark-ye, sirrah!—you know the oak that stands near my house in the country—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Perfectly well, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: It has been the reformer of manners twenty miles round the country—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Ay! Sir, it has been felt with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: I have ordered a good cudgel to be lopped for me, and, if there is any deception in this, thy shoulders shall answer.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Every word most religiously true, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Very well! may be so—it has an air—I am glad I have found this out—The prodigal! the blockhead!—you may go home, Sir—I can take upon me to discharge you from the suspicion you stand under here—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—and I shall ever—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: And if I ever detect you in any more plottings—if you are again the confederate of that absurd blockhead!

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Transport me, Sir, if ever again—Well off, Brisk, well off!—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: So—so—I have found out the young graceless, have I?—mighty well! and if I don't exert the authority of a father—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p:
To be locked up in this manner with an old rogue of a guardian!—Mr. Belford! Mr. Bel
ford! why won't you be my deliverer?—He knows I like him; I have told him so a thousand times; that is my eyes have told him so—And yet he under
takes nothing—One would think the young men of this age have not hearts in their bosoms bigger than pin's heads!—Ah! my dear protector!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: My blossom!—my lovely little ward! to-morrow makes you the queen of my heart; and your will shall be a law to me.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: You only flatter me;—you won't let yourself be ruled by me—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
I shall live under your absolute com
mand, rose-bud!—But you must be mild in autho
rity, for you know—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Yes, I know how tender you have been—your confining me here for so many days is to me a proof of the tenderest love.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Yes, it is a mark of my affection—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: There are many reasons why I should not venture abroad—more than you deam of—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: You alarm me—what reasons?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Why the danger is—no—you'll be for fighting the odious man—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: No—I'll not fight—I'll live for you—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: But will you follow my advice, and speak to him calmly, without passion?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
I will—Let me hear—what's the mat
ter?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Why that Mr. Belford, whose visits you used to encourage—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I have not liked him a good while—what of him?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Oh! he's a wicked man—He has vile designs in his head, and would fain have me listen to his proposals—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: The impudence of the young men of this age!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p:
Your back is no sooner turned, than he raps at the door, and at the windows, and disgraces me with all the neighbours—my character will be ruined [pretends to cry] unless you find some me
thod to—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Don't be alarmed, my sweet—I'll bar my doors, and you shan't stir out this twelvemonth—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: That won't do—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Then you shall never go out at all—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: That's some comfort—But in the mean time to have my reputation blasted by an abandoned libertine [she cries.] Caesar's wife should not only be virtuous, but free from suspicion—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: The sensible girl! this is owing to her education—her sister Mary Ann could not make such a remark—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Well! well!—you don't love me—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Yes, but I do—I'll go and swear the peace against him—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I wish you would—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I'll do it directly—I'll let him know by a justice's warrant that Caesar's wife is not to be trifled with—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: And pray tell him, I hate him—that he may come as often as he will under my window, but it will be to no purpose, for I shall not endeavour to let him in—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: He shall hear it—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Let him know that tho' he is young and handsome, that all his charms are lost upon me—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I'll do it—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p:
Tell him you have been a father to me,—
that I consider you still as my father, and that I think it unnatural to love giddy young men, when I can be so much better off with you.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: He shall hear it on every side of his ears—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Ay, but without loss of time, if you love me—I shan't be easy till he knows my mind—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Nor I—it is fit he should know your mind—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Yes, and tell him, if he should come when you are out, not all his winning ways shall prevail on me run away with him—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: You have charmed me; transported me; ravished me; get up-stairs—I'll seek him this moment—ha! ha!—this all springs from her good sense—this is knowing right from wrong—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p:
Be sure you tell him every word—and if Mr. Belford does but understand every word, as I intend it, then I may still wing my flight to his dear arms—A new scheme this of mine!—But love in
spired it, and love may crown it with success—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p:
Yes, yes, Bridget—the gentleman's gene
rous enow, for a matter o'that.

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: And pray, Peter, do the London folk always give money to the like of we, as often as they come in or out of the house?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Ay! zure, and the sarving folk call it vails. Why, Bridget, poor servants would not be able to ape all their master's follies, and powder like fine gentry, and curse and swear like lords, an so be every body did not give at street door more than any thing they get in the house is worth.

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: La! well that's pure, sure enow!

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p:
As to me, do ye zee, I does not care how often the gentleman comes, and for a matter o'that, I does not care how long master stays in the coun
try—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: These London ways are comical, that's for sure. [a rap at the door] More grise to the mill—go and open the door, Peter—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Go yourself, an you go to that—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: I shall budge none, not I.—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Nor, I, faith and troth!

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Law, how can you be so cross—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: You put all upon me, that's your way—who's at the door—
open the door, you varlets, open the door.

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Oh! it's master—I'll go—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Master!—then I'll go—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Stand out of the way, can't you?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Stand away yourself—I be ready—ben't I!

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Farther a field, will you?
Within there, open the door, I say—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Call here to Peter—he won't let a body—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p:
No body shall but I— [opens the door] Ser
vant master.

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Welcome home, master.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Why am I to wait thus?

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: It was all his doings—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: It was all her doings as well as I.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Peace, numskulls!—how is every body at home?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Charmingly well.

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: All in pure health, praise for every thing; and Miss Mary Ann sings about the house like a little bird in a cage.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Has not she been melancholy since I went into the country?

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: No, Lord love her, not she—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Yes!—how terrible he looks!—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Did not she long for my return?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Hugeously! so we did all—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Vixen! jade! villain! rascal!

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: I'm down o'my knees—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: So be I—merciful father, how—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: You have obeyed my orders, have you? That scoundrel that was lurking here about my house, he is sent to Newgate by this time

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Don't send I to Newgate, pray—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: He'll murder us both, as sure as a gun—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: What you are a sneaking away, are you? Oh! it's all too true—come back, or—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: No, Sir—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Oh! Mary Ann! Mary Ann!—I could never have imagined—call Mary Ann hither—

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Yes, Sir

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Now will they plot, and put their heads together—Mary Ann!—Marry Ann!—Oh! here she comes.

div.stage: Enter Mary Ann, playing with a cup and ball.

sp.p: Three children sliding on the ice—so, you be come, I see—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Yes, I am come home—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Better late than never—I began to think as how you had forgot poor I—I expected you all the live long, long day, so I did, and there did not go by a coach or a cart, or an horse or an ass, but I thought it was you—ah! I am glad you're come—what's the matter?—ben't you well?—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Fatigued after my journey—you have been very well, I hope, since I left you—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Oh! yes, purely—neither sick nor sorry not I—by goles, that is not true neither, for last night—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Last night!—what of last night?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Little Pompey barked so all night long, I could not sleep a wink—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Is that all?—you have not been out any where, have you?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Out!—law, where should I go?— I don't like going out in this strange outlandish place—I like the country better by half—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Well! well! you shall go back soon.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: But then mayn't I go and see sister Harriet first?—an ill natured thing that's what she is—she has not been to see poor I ever since I came to the great town.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: You shall see her—so you passed your time very merrily!

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Oh! never better in all my days—but you don't seem glad to see a body—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I am glad to see you—the little Jezabel won't tell me a word [aside]—shall I tax her with it directly, or wait a little longer to see her cunning?—let you and I go and chat a little together above stairs.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! you look cross—with all heart I'll go—one two, three, and away—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: The little frippery, how she carries it off!—Oh! the devil! I burn, I'm in a fever—I have had the grass cut under my feet—Oh! the young Magdalen!—the sly iniquity!—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
Nature never designed me for a knight errant—Don Quixote would have stormed fifty cas
tles, while my dull brain is hatching one poor pro
ject—what must be done?—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ay! ay! there he is, I see—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: 'Sdeath no way to convey a message to her!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Full of mischief!—your servant, Sir—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Mr. Lovibond!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I was in quest of you.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: 'Tis a mark of your friendship—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I mean to prove my friendship, do you see—I don't like to see young men losing their time—it is now fit you should understand yourself, and fix upon something that may settle your head a little—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Ah! Sir!—'tis in your power—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ay! much is in my power—I have a fair ward, Mr. Belford—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: He is going to propose her to me [aside.] I know her perfectly, Sir—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Then I don't inform you of it—she is handsome, spirited, and sensible—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I am no stranger to her merit—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
Then I don't inform you of that nei
ther; to-morrow I intend to gratify the wishes of her heart, and make her mine by marriage—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: What so soon, Sir?—this is news—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
Then I inform you of it—and I will in
form you of another thing too—She has a mortal aversion to you, and desires you will trouble her no more —

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: You amaze me, Sir—the devil! she has not blabbed to him, I hope.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: What a mortified countenance he puts on!

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
This is all an absolute riddle, Mr. Lovi
bond.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
Then I'll unriddle it to you—she per
ceived you dangling after her in all public places, whenever I took her abroad with me;—she under
stood those artful glances you cast towards her; she
could interpret every amourous sigh;—she bid me tell you so—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: She did?—then perhaps I know how to interpret her meaning.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
She says you may think her a melan
choly prisoner, but you may spare your walks up and down the street; and so she would have acquainted you long ago, but she wanted a proper person to convey her sentiments to you.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: She has found a trusty messenger at last.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! so she has—she knows she could trust me—ha! ha!—I thought it a pity you should lose any more time, and so now you may go and bow, and kneel, and make a monkey of your
self before some other window—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
Since is so, Sir, I must submit—her mean
ing is deeper than he is aware of.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Don't be dishearten'd—you may succeed elsewhere—she allows you to be of a very comely figure; a well proportioned person; but 'tis all lost upon her; she considers me as her father, and has no unnatural passion for profligate youngsters.—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
I believe you, Sir—I desist from all pre
tension;—I see this matter now in its true light;—and, Sir, I shall molest you no more; and in that determination I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Not so fast;—another word—tho' you were to watch your time, and in my absence scale the wall, and get in at the window, and entreat her to elope with you, she still would cleave to me.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: That I dare say—I'll try her tho'— [aside]—I am perfectly satisfied, Sir—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: And harkye;—you may come as often as you will about the house, she will not exchange a word with you out of the window—nor settle any scheme with you—ha! ha! you see you are fully understood—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
I shall ever esteem you as my friend, and I shall lose no more time, that you may tell the lady
—she shall never have reason to upbraid me again—and so you may assure her—ten thousand blessings on her for this stratagem;—she shall be mine this very night.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: What a look of chagrin there was!—I have trained the girl up to this—ha! ha! Mary Ann will never have sense enough to behave in this manner—ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: A pretty sort of jeopardy I have been in, master!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Traitor! let me see no more of you.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: And are those my thanks, Sir?—You'll be so good as to give me a discharge—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I wish I could give you a discharge of a culverin—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p:
I am not so extravagant in my expectations as to desire that favour, Sir—Heav'n help me! I am more easily contented—Only just a small arrear of wages, if you please, with a little dash of a character for diligence, fidelity, and a smattering of what you call parts, if my master did not mar all upon occa
sion, and leave now and then in danger of dangling by the neck for attempting to serve him—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: You are a villain!

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: I am a fool!—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
Have not you betrayed me to Sir The
odore?—let him into my whole secret?—He knew nothing of my being in love in town here, but you must divulge it, and I must have him storming at me in a rage and fury—I must have my best con
certed schemes disappointed by you—Begone, rascal, I have done with you—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Mighty well, Sir!—what possesses him? only please, Sir, to settle that trifling balance—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
Ha! Brumpton! give me joy—things begin to wear a better aspect—I'll swear you are right—ha! ha! I intend for the future to be a laugh
ing philosopher too—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Philosophy may go to Bridewell for ought I care, unless philosophy could pimp for a body—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Hey! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Every thing's the matter—ask that treacherous—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Mr. Belford, believe me, Sir—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Hold you your tongue, Sir—no more of your—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
Ha! ha!—what out of temper! My af
fairs, Brumpton, are in a fair way—you, after a great deal of pains, may possibly be disappointed, but I—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Po! po! this is all—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
I have messages sent me from the girl I adore, you rogue—she points out my road to hap
piness.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I'm not dispos'd to laughter—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
Pshaw! man, never fret for little disap
pointments—have you any difficulties? you have strength to remove mountains—Ha! ha!—my dear Brumpton, you send messages, I am sent to—you are disappointed,—I am likely to succeed—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, Sir, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
Not I, truly—If I must die, I'll die laugh
ing, like Pierre in the tragedy, ha! ha!—You make a toil of a pleasure, Brumpton; and love, which is to me joy and rapture, is to you—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Damnation!—draw this moment—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
No—no—our tempers are very different—what, I'm in too high spirits, and you want to let me a little blood—you fret, I laugh—ha! ha!—
I'll leave you to recover your usual spirits—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
'Sdeath, this is insupportable!—I have but one scheme left—Brisk, you must execute it di
rectly—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: There is no disguise necessary, I hope, Sir—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: No murmuring, scoundrel; follow me this instant—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: This will be an horsepond business, I fear, and a ducking will spoil my livery.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: It was well said by an old philosopher, when you are in a passion con over your alphabet.—I have done so, and have recovered my temper—walk in Mary Ann, walk in—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah!—you have not taken any notice of me since you came home—ah! I see you don't love me—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
You are much mistaken—I love you ex
ceedingly—draw a chair—sit down—Well! and how have you passed your time in my absence?—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: As well as any thing.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Have you any news?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: News!—law, not I—fikins, I fib tho'—I have news to tell you—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Have you?—what is it, chicken?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Little kitten's dead.—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Indeed!—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! if you had seen all its pretty little tricks, and how it played about—It grieved me to lose she—but squirrel's well—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Is he?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Yes, and so is mackaw—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Ay, that's good news—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Yes, and I have marked three shirts, and hemmed five handkerchiefs—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
Mighty well! [pauses, and looks at her earnestly] Mary Ann,—this is a wide and dangerous world we live in—scandal, malice, and detraction are ever flying about,—constantly on the wing, and spreading pernicious tales to the ruin of every cha
racter.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: You frighten a body, you talk so—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
Draw near, sweet, draw near—you look charmingly—mind what I say—some impertinent neigh
bours have whispered—but I did not believe 'em—they have said, that while I was in the country, a young gentleman frequented here, and was well re
ceived, Mary Ann—But I have laid a wager there was no foundation for any such idle givings out—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: How much have you laid?—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Five pounds to four—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: All that!—make a hedge of it, as you did at the horse-race—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Cause, you'll lose—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Then there was a young gentleman here—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: As sure as a gun—He was here for ever and for ever—morning, noon, and night—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: But, my little lambkin, did not I forbid any visits?—I won't be certain, but if my memory does not fail me—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Oh! for a matter o'that, you may be certain—you did forbid it, sure enough.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: And why was I disobeyed, my dear?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! you would have done the same yourself—as the song says

div.l: Had you been in my place,
Why you'd ha' done the same.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Very prettily sung—but explain, my sweet—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: It's the surprisingest thing in the world—I'll tell you all about it—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: That's right; let us hear—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: I was sitting in the balcony, thinking of no earthly thing, and he passed by on the other side of the way—Ah! he looked as handsome as an angel—and so he made me a low bow—I blushed up to my very ears, and so I got up, and made a low curtesy—and so he kissed his hand, and I could not help smiling at that, and so he bowed again and again, and I curtesyed again and again, and then he walked up the street, and down the street, and to and fro, and backwards and forwards; and would you believe it?—He did not miss a time making me a bow with all the good nature in the world, and so I was as good natured as he, and if he had staid all night long, I should have staid too, for I thought it would not be right to be out done in civility—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Oh! those damned bal illegible nies, I always hated them—well! well! go on, Mary Ann.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p:
Well, and so the next day a large, comely fat gentlewoman came to me, and she had three or four band-boxes full of fine things, and she said she had orders to give me my choice of charm
ing lace, and charming ribbons,—Ay! and she seemed very good-natured, and spoke in the prettiest manner—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Oh! the execrable bawd!—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p:
You are very pretty, my dear, says she, but it's a pity you should be mewed up here—and then she offered me to take me home to her own house, and said she would dizen me out with dia
monds, and then a lord would fall in love with me—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: The infernal sorceress!

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p:
And then she said I had done a great deal of mischief, and that I wounded a young gen
tleman terribly—Who, I wound any body, says I?—Yes, the gentleman I saw in the balcony—I was as sorry as any thing I had hurt him, but I could not tell how it was, and she said it was my eyes, and that he
was shot thro' the heart, and would be dead and buried in two days time, if I did not see him—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Oh! the damned agent of hell.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p:
And then, could you think of her good
ness? Indeed I can't help loving her for it—She offered me to go and meet the young gentleman at her house—I thanked her, and took it very kind—but I did not care to go to strange places, and so I said the gentleman might come here if he would—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Oh! the travelling milliner! [aside.] Well, and did he come?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: That he did sure enough—and he said the very sight of me cured him of his wounds—Ah! I am sure you can't blame me, for I could not let him die, so I could not—I almost cried my eyes out when little kitten died—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Brother Lovibond is right—she has it I fear;—Oh! I dread the rest.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah!—but you are angry now—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
No—not angry—well—how did he be
have?—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! he had such a pretty smile—and he gave me this twee—and he gave Bridget and Peter whole handfuls of money.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: What did he say?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Oh! the prettiest words in the world.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: But he did not touch you?—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: By goles, I beg your pardon for that, but he did, though—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I guessed so— [aside.]—Go on—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p:
He kissed one a thousand and a thou
sand times—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Daggers! daggers! daggers!

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: And squeezed my hand so tenderly.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Poison! wormwood! wormwood!

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: He took one round the neck—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I thought as much [aside.]—proceed—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: And round the waist, and he—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
Now—now—it's all over—how I trem
ble!

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: What's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Nothing—we shall have some rain—my corn shoots; that's all—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: And he [she smiles at him.] Ah! but I won't tell you—you'll be angry—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: No—no—no—I love you dearly, Mary Ann; [laughs uneasily.] I do indeed—go on with your story, go on—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Why then, he took my glove off, and almost eat my hand up with kisses—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: But was that all?—did you do nothing more to cure his wounds?—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Look you there now—you are angry—ought I to have done more?

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: No;—enough of all conscience;—but, are you sure this was all?—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: He gave me this fan, and a pair of ear-rings; and I am sure it was very civil of him to shew so much good nature to a stranger.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Mary Ann, Mary Ann, all his smooth words, all his tenderness, all his smiles, were baits to entrap you, to ensnare, to deceive you, abuse you, ruin you—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! but he told me to the contrary, over and over, and over again—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
I know the world, child—it was all for your destruction, to swallow you up in the jaws of ruin—go up to your room—all this shall be ex
plained to you—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! but you are out of humour with a body.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Do as I bid you—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Yes, that's what I will—By goles, he's a sweet gentleman, for all you, that's what he is [aside.]

div.p:
What an escape have I had! and yet her ingenuous manner of confessing all, gives me some hopes—I'll read her a lecture, and then I'll go and let Sir The
odore Brumpton know what a villain his son is—Oh! Mary Ann, Mary Ann.

div.head: ACT III.
div.p:
MY dear good nature, hold you your tongue!—You plead in vain, not a step will I budge. [striking his bosom] I am rock, and will be made a dupe no more;—well said, my just resentment; we know the world now, and will be led a devil's dance no longer—Bravo Brisk, now you are free, and your own man again—Service is a very unthankful office, and for the mere honour of—Pshaw! pox!—now my honour must be heard—What will the world say of you, Mr. Brisk, you that have hitherto been the first footman in England, renowned for your parts and your abilities!—what give way now to a trifling difficulty? money is absolutely necessary for your master's affairs, Mr. Oldcastle is his only resource, and you have orders to apply for it directly—But my dear honour, you know what an empty bubble you are, and how often I have been kicked in your ser
vice—The more glory, man;—If any body thinks it
worth his while to kick you, it's a sign you are rising in the world—those are the true marks of a footman's genius; those are the things that will raise you in the world, and make an exciseman of you at last! Bravo! I kindle at the thought—I must go on; one effort more, Brisk, and then—But how! how! touch the cash!—"My master is in the utmost distress, Sir, and will be for ever obliged to you"—Pshaw! that will never do—I have a stratagem, and if I can but meet with master Oldcastle—ha! as luck will have it—courage Brisk!—here he comes—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: What a discovery have I made!—I'll let his father, I'll let Sir Theodore know—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Oh! Sir!—I am glad I have met you at last—I have sought you thro' the whole town—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: You live with young Brumpton, don't you?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p:
The same, Sir—such a tide of affairs coming upon him—such an unforeseen accident—poor Sir Theodore, Sir!—the good worthy gentle
man, on his way from the country—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I understood he was in town—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p:
He was coming to town, Sir; we expected him every hour—and now the fatal news is arrived—He was taken suddenly ill, too great a fulness of blood—no assistance near—it happened on the road—no surgeon—no barber to bleed him—the poor gen
tleman expired—and in the most critical moment—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Carried off in this manner you say, and without having time to be ill!—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p:
Yes, Sir;—without a single consultation of physicians!—It's very hard!—It's a pity he was in such a haste to die—but good sometimes comes of evil, they say—The news has wrought a wonderful change in my young master—Sir Theodore had made a match for him in the country—a great match in
deed!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Ay! I heard of it—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: And yet the son, perverse and obstinate, was in love here in town,—that is, he fancied he was—with an insignificant hussey, and was determined to marry her, in opposition to his poor father.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I have heard of that too—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: But he is now shocked that he should be such a monster of disobedience, and he gives up all thought of this town lady—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: That's right—the good young man—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p:
Ay! the good young gentleman, indeed—He renounces her for ever, Sir, and is resolved to go off immediately for the country, and after he has per
formed the last duty to the best of men, who is now no more, he is determined to pay that regard to his me
mory which he refused to his authority, when living, and marry no woman in the world but the woman de
signed for him by his father.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: The good young man!—this is the best news I ever heard in my life [aside] the good young man!

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: But then his intention of going out of town, I fear, may be frustrated.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: As how! that must not be—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p:
Why we were kept a little bare of cash lat
terly, just to reduce him to a sense of his duty—and now he wants wherewithal to discharge some little bills, before we set out for the country—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Why, I am indebted to Sir Theodore's estate—the intentions of the young man must not be frustrated—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Heaven forbid!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Here, I have in a purse here—Ha! ha! I shall get rid of a plague and a torment [aside]—I can let him have a couple of hundreds— [holds out the purse to him] and tell him he can't go out of town too soon—good lack! poor Sir Theodore—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: My son bid me speak to him, and luckily here he is—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: [in amaze] Ye powers of heaven!—ye guardian Gods!—assist me! help me!—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: [in a mock tone] Angels and ministers of grace! what a damned accident is this!—let us run away, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Hey! what's the matter?—what do the people stare at?—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I am all over in a jelly! [drops the purse] Brisk, support me, lend me your arm—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: I have not strength—but crawling on the ground—he'll carry away your purse—you know he always loved money— [Brisk makes towards the purse]

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—in the name of wonder, what possesses you?—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Disappear, for heaven's sake, disappear—I never did you wrong—I'll pay the money to your executor—I was advancing your son two hundred pounds in part-payment; I never saw a ghost in all my days before—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: What! do you think I'm dead, Mr. Oldcastle?—Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: And be you alive?

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: As sure as you are alive man—Ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I took you for a ghost [striking Brisk with his cane] Sirrah, let that money alone—hold me, Sir Theodore, hold me,—I am ready to sink into the earth [Goes up to him] they told me you was dead—that fellow Brisk—Hey! what are you running away with my money—scoundrel! villain! robber!

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: May be you are used to ghosts, Sir; I can't stay in a place that's haunted.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p:
Compose yourself; and let me under
stand this business—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
[laying hold of him] I protest you are a
live—that son of yours! he kills his father, before he is dead—that abettor of his mischiefs!—he told me you was carried off suddenly, and now my two hun
dred pounds is carried off suddenly.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: I am thunder-struck!—I am as much amazed as you was this moment!—You shock me, Mr. Oldcastle—Could my son engage in such a scene of wickedness?

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
I am sorry to say it; but I fear he is a very wicked young man—they have imposed upon me; he has robbed me—this money is got for the vi
lest purposes, to enable him to fly in your face, and carry off a little wench that is not worth a groat.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Not worth a groat!—and he had the assurance to refer me to you-said she had an estate, that there was a borough upon it, and that you knew all the particulars.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Borough upon her estate!—ha! ha! yes, yes, I know the particulars; lackaday, Sir Theodore, who do you think she is?—a milliner's 'prentice that has eloped from her mistress.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: My blood fires at him—I am out of all patience Mr. Oldcastle—thus my family is to be disgraced by a worthless hair-brained blockhead!—a milliner's 'prentice!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Even so!

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: The fool! the coxcomb! the—here, I'll pay you back your money—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: No, you need not do that—get it back from him—it will burn in his pocket—the sooner he leaves the town the better; I shall be at ease, if I once hear he is gone—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Mr. Oldcastle, you are very good to feel so much concern in this affair—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Yes, I have a deep concern in it; but hark ye, Sir Theodore—don't let him know you had your information from me—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: No—you may depend upon me—not a syllable.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: When he is gone, I shall sleep in peace—I said I would do him a good turn with his father.

div.p:
How my heart it beats!—post haste—gallop! gal
lop! and no wonder; it's a dangerous experiment I have tried—could I but convey this letter—Mr. Belford then would know my meaning—hush! here comes my turn-key!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
Well Harriet, I have executed your com
mission—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: How did he receive it?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: He was very much mortified, tho' I thought I marked, as he went off, an odd sort of a dry constrained smile.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p:
But I shall have no more reason to com
plain of him, I hope.—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha! I almost pitied the poor devil—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: He deserves no pity, Mr. Lovibond—he is a sad wretch—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
I believe it—But he knows he was enga
ged in a vain pursuit;—he said so himself, and bid me assure you he would lose no more time.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: That revives me;—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: No—no—he will hardly come this way again.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I don't know what to say to that—I dread the contrary—I am afraid he will not renounce me for ever so easily as you may imagine—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: And, pray, what reason have you for thinking so?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I have terrible proofs against him—while you was out he came again under my window.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ay!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I ran away at the sight of him—but the window being open, he flung this little box into the room with a letter in it.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: A letter in it!—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Yes, the wicked contriver! a letter in it—I ran to the window to throw it to him again, but he was gone, and then it occurred to me that it might not be quite so prudent to throw it into the street, lest it should fall into the hands of malicious people, who might misinterpret appearances to my disadvantage.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: That was wisely judged.—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I have been ever since thinking that it ought to be returned, and if I had a proper person—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Who so proper as myself? let me have it.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: No—no—it would affront him more if delivered by a common porter.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
