sp.p: Excuse me, I am the fittest person—a letter in a box!—what contrivances they have!—I'll take care he shall have it, and he will look so silly when he perceives all his schemes are blasted.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Why indeed, it will astonish him the more, if you deliver it—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: So it will—ha! ha!—it will be a rare stroke of revenge—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: [she laughs] The newest that ever was—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I like it of all things—but first let me see the contents of his letter—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Dear heart, not for the world—would you give the horrid man room to imagine that a girl of character would so much as open the seal of his filthy letter?—let me advise, Mr. Lovibond; to return it unopened will be the strongest mark of contempt, and the greatest affront that can be put upon him—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: There is something in that—your wisdom charms me—you endear yourself to me more and more every hour—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: You'll use your own discretion whether to open it or not—But the reasons I have given—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
Are to me conclusive—I'll about this bu
siness directly—ha! ha! we'll put the greatest affront in the world upon him—ha! ha! the truest mark of contempt, ha! ha! good-by, rose-bud, good-by.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Yes, yes, let him have it unopened—If this plot takes, I shall have my utmost wish—and making him my convenient, my go-between in the business, gives life and spirit to the plot—I'll outwit him, if I can—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Admirably managed, Brisk! now I have the sinews of war — tossing up a purse.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: It was got out of the fire, I promise you, Sir—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Your services are of higher value for it—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
And yet I fear my services may one day or other bring me to—What do you think your fa
ther will say to me?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Po! absurd—Mr. Oldcastle will talk matters over with him—I desired my father to make it his business to see my friend Oldcastle—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: You desired him to do that, did you?—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Yes, I desired him—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: And his coming was owing to you—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
Yes, yes;—ha! ha!—it was I occa
sioned that—I desired him to go—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p:
Then pray desire any body else but Brisk to go on your errands for the future—more misfortunes!—here comes Sir Theodore; settle it as well as
you can with him—I wash my hands of it, and now legs do your office.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: So, Sir! [pauses, and looks at him] Thou graceless!—thou ungrateful!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: What's in the wind now?

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Easy, calm unfeeling prodigal!—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Sir, these are words that—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p:
That you deserve, and worse, if in
dignation did not choak them here—look ye, Sir, I spared no pains in your education;—expence, indul
gence, care, affection, all that a fond father could be
stow, were yours—I hoped to see you a young man of principle, governed by sentiments of honour, a credit, and a comfort to me—but what a sad reverse of all this!—Your reputation gone, your character blasted, and vile expedients every day made use of.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir, this bitterness of reproach—how have I deserved—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: How deserved!— [pauses, and looks at him] and dare you ask the question?—refund that money, Sir,—the two hundred pounds, out of which you have gulled an easy worthy friend of mine—restore it this moment, or perhaps it may be the last you will ever handle—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: And where is the mighty harm, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: I have no patience with you—I have lived too long for you, have I?—The sand lingers in the glass, and you want to shake it out!—return that money this instant, or never look me in the face again—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: If it must be so, Sir,—but if you will please to hear me—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p:
Po! po!—I have full conviction—for the meanest purposes too this stratagem was con
trived!—to run counter to my will, and carry off a little obscure girl—and so live despised—a scandal to your father, and a laughing stock to all your ac
quaintance
—go, and reform, set out for the country directly, or never darken my doors again—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
What the devil can I make of all this!—I am certainly out of luck to-day—It does not sig
nify—I'll pursue Mary Ann with more spirit than ever—I'll to her house this moment,—since diffi
culties come in my way, genius must surmount them, that's all.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: A mortal sin!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
Yes, a mortal sin!—you are unexperi
enced in these matters—It is a sin, child, to accept of presents from men, twees, fans, and Brussels lace,—Brussels lace has done as much mischief as the for
bidden fruit—I wish I had bred her up a Quaker aside mind my words—to indulge wanton young men in liberties with your person,—to let 'em fold you round the waist, play with your neck, and print lascivious kisses on your lips, 'tis the sure road to de
struction—'tis horrible, Mary Ann, horrible and abominable—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p:
Ah! but I don't believe that—and a pity it should, for [smiling at him] it's very agreea
ble—I am sure I like it better than questions and com
mands, or the fool in the middle, or hide and go seek, either —

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I tell you they are all abominable things till the marriage-ceremony is performed—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: And is it allowed then?

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Then, and then only, Mary Ann—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: [smiling.] By goles, I am glad to hear that, and so marry me as soon as you will—I shall be pure and happy with him, then—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Why, with that sweet charming young—Ah! look you there—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Hold, beware, Mary Ann—I marry you for myself only—you must despise and detest all others—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! I never shall find it in my heart to hate him—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
It will be the destruction of you even to think of him—Look you, child; mark well my ad
monitions— [sits down.] Come hither—hold up your head, child,—Listen attentively— [he raises her head.] I take you to my bed, Mary Ann, my true and law
ful wife—But take heed—for but now you was tum
bling headlong down the gulph of perdition—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: I wish you would let me go and feed my birds.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
Compose your thoughts, I say—Mar
riage is an holy institution, and exacts rigorous duties on the part of the wife—you must love, honour, and obey your husband, therefore be upon your guard—the enemy of womankind is for ever prowling about in quest of prey, always ready to seduce, to mur
der, and devour, and swallow up in the jaws of ruin every frail young creature that comes in his way—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: [bursts into tears.] But they shan't swallow me up, so they shan't—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Ay! ay! this will do her good—Come, come, dry up your tears

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: [sobbing.] I did not do any thing to be run away with in the jaws of ruin, so I did not—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: No—no—all will be well—'tis for your good I speak—so—so—so—have done crying—I know you'll be good—there—make me a curtesy—mighty well—be a good girl—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! but they shan't murder, and devour me, for there are folks enough in London all hours of the day to assist a body; and if he comes in the night, I can call the watch, so I can—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I am pleased with her simplicity—This young profligate that you have let into my house, if he should c illegible me under your window again—That's right—I have a thought—you shall fling him out all his presents—you shall write him a letter, and tell him what a monster he is,—Come, take that chair—sit down—take that pen, and write as I dictate to you—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p:
[sitting down.] Law! I does not un
derstand all this—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: [walking about.] Write as I dictate—Come, begin—Mr. Brumpton [goes to the side of the scene.] Peter, bring me up a candle—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: "Dear Mr. Brumpton!—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Mr. Brumpton, and no more—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: [smiling aside]—Very well—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: [walking about.] You are a vile man, and your visits I now see sprung from a bad design—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: [aside.] Ah! I don't like those words—By goles [smiling as his back is turned.] I know what I'll do— [stifling a laugh.] I have wrote it—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: To ruin my future happiness—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Happiness—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Your intention is base,—and unworthy of a gentleman—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Very well—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
You are odious in your person;—detesta
ble in your morals—and the scorn of all our sex—have you wrote it?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Stay—stay—then—all our sex—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I am in love with Mr. Biddulph.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Write as I bid you—I am in love with Mr. Biddulph,—a worthy good gentleman—and out of his hands—it never shall be in your power—to seduce me—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: [smiling.] Very well—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Therefore let me never see you any more—Mary Ann Richley.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Mary Ann Richley—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Now let me read it—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah!—stay, stay a moment—Not quite done—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Here be the candle, master—the gentleman is walking under the window now—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
Is he?—make haste—fold up the let
ter—let me do it—let me do it, make haste—come, come, dispatch, he'll be gone, else—you shall throw it to him now, and all his presents—come, come, make haste.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! I am ready—I like this of all things—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Once more well met, Sir.—You can write I fancy, can't you?—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: The drift of that question, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
I fancy you know this little bauble— shewing a box. You don't know it to be sure, no, nor the letter in the inside—here take it back—I charge nothing for the postage—you have it un
opened, in statu quo— [opens the box.] Look ye here; ha!—no direction upon it—that was cunning—here, here, you have it in good order, and well conditioned as it came—ha! ha!—Harriet will not read a word of it—she had no curiosity about it—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: But I have [aside, and taking the letter, opens it.] heavens bless her wit—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ay! You know the hand-writing—Take notice you broke the seal yourself—none of us read a word of it—We return it unopened, to make the affront the deeper.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I believe you, Sir—I see you never read a word of it—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
Not a syllable—her pride would not suf
fer it—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Well, since it is come to this, being out of humour will avail nothing—Ha! ha! I can't help laughing—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: That's pleasant of you—Ha! ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Yes, very pleasant—Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: See what your intrigues are come to—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Yes, Sir,—you have brought 'em to a fine pass—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ay!—you see I am not to be tricked—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Mr. Lovibond, I am wild with joy—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: And so am I—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Who is that old fellow?

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I have managed matters charmingly—Who is that spark?—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
You need not be shy of him—I'll ven
ture to say you have not managed as well as I have, Mr. Old—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Call me Biddulph.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
Well! I fancy you will toss no more let
ters in at the window.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: No truly, Sir, not I—and I beg you will assure the lady that—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
Ay! let us hear—you need not mind this gentleman—come, come, let us hear—now bro
ther Old—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Call me Biddulph—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ay! now hear him, Mr. Biddulph.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
I beg the lady's pardon, Sir—I resign, myself to her inclinations, and shall obey her com
mands—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Very well—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: You are too powerful a rival, and since it is so, you will be pleased to tell her I most heartily approve of the choice she has made—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Do you hear that?— to Oldcastle.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Her superior sense shines forth in every action of her life, and, Sir, I will only add that I shall never give her cause to complain again—you will report me to the lady, and, Sir, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: There, there, you see what an happy man I am—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Well, and now let me tell you

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
I can't stay to hear—I am in the ele
ments with joy—brother Oldcastle, your servant—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
But, brother Lovibond, let me tell you—po! an envious man, he can't bear a neighbour's hap
piness—lackaday! I wish he had staid, for here comes that graceless young—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Brumpton—the young dog, nothing affects him [aside] Well, and your intrigues, how go they on?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Oh!—I longed to see you—you have not been able to reconcile my father, I find—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
No, I did all I could—I spoke very hand
somely of you to Sir Theodore, I assure you—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: And yet he is worse than ever—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: He is very positive—well! but the business of your love—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Why, it was likely to be somewhat embarrassed—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I long to hear it. [aside] As how pray?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: The old curmudgeon is returned from the country—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Ay!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: The servants have changed their tone, and the door is shut in my face.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I can't help laughing—ha! ha! this Mr. Biddulph knows what he is about, I fancy—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
Po!—the fellow is fitter to have the funeral service read over him than the marriage ce
remony—he made her come to the balcony—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Well! and how was that?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
He muffled himself up behind the cur
tain,—I could not distinguish him—she threw me out some trinkets, I had given her—But, my dear friend, she flung a letter with 'em—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I long to hear about that—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: The contents of it amazed me—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I dare say—she told you her mind, I reckon—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Most freely, most openly—ha! ha! old Nostrodamus is outwitted—for, look you here—here in her own fair hand—ten thousand blessings on her [kisses the letter] Here, Sir, the genuine dictates of her heart—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: He is mad, sure!—let me see it—

p.q: Dear Mr. Brumpton, you are a charming man, and your civilities, I am sure sprung, from an honest design, for my future happiness.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: In the name of wonder, what is all this!

p.q: Your intentions are generous, and worthy of a gentleman—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: The little hypocritical sorceress!

p.q:
You are handsome in your person,—and your manners also; and the admira
tion of all our sex—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Oh! the Jezebel!

p.q: I hate Mr. Biddulph, an odious old wretch; and

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: The vile harlotry!

p.q:
And out of my guardian's hands, it is in your power to relieve me—Yours
indeed, and indeed, until death us do part—Mary Ann Richley.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: —She has reversed every word of it!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: There's an adventure! ha! ha! ha!—is not she a charming girl? you don't partake of my joy.—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Partake of your joy—I—I—I—yes.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: What a way old Biddulph will be in!—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Why, I must say I feel for him—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Feel for him! a wretch like that!—so ungenerous a guardian,—so base a betrayer of his trust! who could offer his withered superannuated love to the sweetest girl, and with the winter of old age nip so much beauty in its bud!—January and May joined together!—does not that make you laugh?—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I am afraid of laughing, tho' I love it of all things—it sets me a coughing always—well! but trouble may come of all this—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Never be uneasy—an't you amazed at my success?

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I am, indeed—I never was so confounded in all my days aside I wish as heartily as a minister of state that there was not such a thing as pen, ink, and paper in the kingdom.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: What's the matter with you?—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
A megrim has suddenly taken me—take care what you do—Mr. Oldcastle, you are a block
head, an overweening, cuckoldy blockhead! [aside]—I wish your father mayn't hear of this—Oh! the vile baggage, I must run home directly—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: How indifferent the old muckworm is grown!—but this dear enchanting letter!—Oh! this joy is too powerful—Sir Theodore never made this leg—ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Brumpton, are you in good humour? May I venture to—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Belford, let me embrace you—I tread in air—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: My dear Brumpton, I too am wild with joy—I am out of my senses— walks about humming a tune.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: [hums a different tune.]—Oh! such an unexpected, transporting, ravishing event—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Such a surprize, above all romance—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Oh! Belford, I am the happiest rogue.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Such unutterable bliss, my dear boy—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Her wit is equal to her beauty—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: The greatest stroke of invention,—Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Such a sweet epistle—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: So divine a letter—and the old fellow brought it himself—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: No—no—you mistake; she flung it out of the window.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Po!—I tell you he was the bearer of it himself—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: You are quite wrong; she was in the balcony, and—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Pshaw! give me leave to know—did not I see him?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: There was no seeing him distinctly;—he was skulking behind the curtain—and then she threw the letter down to me,—Oh! the idol of my heart!—the lovely Mary Ann!—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
Mary Ann!—you are the most perplex
ing—'sdeath! I was telling you how my sweet god
dess contrived to send me a letter by her very guar
dian—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
I did not hear a syllable of that mat
ter—I was telling you—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Then I'll tell you how it was—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
No—no—hear the story of my happi
ness.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Nay, nay; mine is the most surprizing.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
Look ye here, my boy [shewing a let
ter.]—the work of her own fingers!

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: There, there— [shewing his letter] more eloquence than in all Cicero.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: [reads.] Dear Mr. Brumpton, you are a sweet man, and your civilities—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
[reads.] You will be surprized at this letter; and more so at the manner of convey
ing it.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: [reads] The admiration of all our sex.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: [reads.] But I must hazard all, or fall a sacrifice to the avarice of my guardian—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: [reads.] And out of his hands it is in your power to relieve me—
sp.stage: both reading at the same time very eagerly.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: [reads.] I love you, Mr. Belford; will you despise me for telling you so? I hope not.
sp.stage: both reading at the same time very eagerly.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
[reads.] Yours indeed, and in
deed, until death us do part, Mary Ann Rich
ley.
sp.stage: both reading at the same time very eagerly.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: [reads.] Contrive some means for my escape, and heaven and earth combined shall not keep you from me—the disconsolate Harriet.
sp.stage: both reading at the same time very eagerly.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: YES, she told me all about the young rake-hell's visits, gave me back his letter unopened, to return it to him with my own hands—Is not she a miracle of goodness and superior sense?

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: It was very sensible—how often will you ask me?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Is not she trained up in the paths that she should walk?—When will Mary Ann do as much?—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Ay! there it stings!—He has heard all, and I am blown!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
I have seen my gentleman since—I have given him his letters;—told him what a mor
tal aversion she has to him; and I warrant me, I have sent him off with a flea in his ear.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I thought to ha' done the same by young Brumpton—but the minx has so bamboozled me!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
You seem disturbed—ha! ha! mor
tified at my success, I suppose—ha! ha!—or some fly-flap has caught Mary Ann, and she, poor thing—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: He has hit the nail o'the head aside.—You need not trouble your head about Mary Ann—leave her to my care, Sir—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: But, Mr. Oldcastle—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: But, brother Lovibond—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: You are the strangest man—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Po! po! you have no friendship for any body.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: No friendship!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: None—all for yourself, and wishing for other people's misfortunes—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
This is your gratitude, Mr. Oldcastle—Did not I help you to a rich young spendthrift, who wanted a thousand pounds; and did not he give you his bond, and then did not I make him draw a bill upon you for the money, and did not I bid you sue him for both the bond and the bill? was not I a wit
ness in the cause for you?—I'll have you indicted for subornation of perjury—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: If you go to that, who taught you to sink ships in the chops of the channel?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: And who shewed you the way to be an engrosser of corn, and a forestaller of markets?

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Your smuggling, Mr. Lovibond—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Your usury, Mr. Oldcastle—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
Mighty well—I see what it's come to—These are the thanks I meet with—I, that first laid the scheme of keeping these girl's fortune all to our
selves—Here ends all intercourse between us; I break off; I have no more to say to you—and so now you know my resolution—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha! what a turmoil the poor man has put himself in!—ha! ha! Things are going wrong with him—I never shall be at rest, till I see the bottom of all this—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p:
And look ye, Sir—If ever you pre
sume to meddle again between father and son—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: I meddle, Sir, between—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: If ever again I lay my finger upon a single act of yours—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p:
Sir, if you would permit me, all this expence of passion might be saved—I have to be sure been caught tripping a little or so; but it is never too late to take up; I have reflected upon the matter, and without any great pretence to more wisdom than falls to the share of the like of me—I have obtain'd
my dismission, and bid adieu to my master's service for ever—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Quitted his service, have you?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I am going down to my father's in the country—My father's in a very pretty way; has some very good farms, and so I think to settle there for the rest of my days—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p:
I am glad of this, sirrah, and since you have left him, I forgive you, do you see;—here, here's something to bear your expences down—I com
mend your resolution much—But hark ye, Brisk—now you are going,—it will be honest of you to in
form me,—it will make some amends for what is past—is my son really in love with this girl?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: At present he is, but law! Sir, if she were once remov'd out of his way—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: That is what I have been thinking of—that would do the business, would not it?—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Most clearly, Sir—out of sight, out of mind with him—If in return for your honour's goodness, by any little service in my poor way—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p:
I thank you, Brisk, I thank you—but there will be no occasion for you—I have employed an elderly body, a good cunning matron-like wo
man, who understands the whole art of laying springes for young damsels.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Nothing can be better imagined, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: She is to insinuate herself into the house, as such people know how to do—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: No doubt, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: And then when she has allured my young madam abroad with her, she shall then be so disposed off, that he may beat the bush long enough, before he finds her, I warrant him—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: You have hit upon the only way in the world, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p:
It is an honest artifice, Brisk, to res
cue the coxcomb from destruction—I wish you well, Brisk, I wish you well.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p:
Health attend your honour!—So, here's a mine detected!—and my master is flying wild about the town, thinking it's all enchanted ground he treads, and at last he'll be blown up in the air—with all my heart let him; let him see how he looks when he comes down again—and yet—there again now, temptations are beginning their old trade—well, something must be done, and so now mine away, Sir Theodore;—be as good a pioneer as you will, I warrant me I'll coun
termine you—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: It's pure lucky, Bridget, he did not find the gentleman in the closet—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p:
He lay close all the time like a mouse in a cheese—and master walked about the room, and gnaw
ed his lip, and gnashed his teeth,—and gave the ta
ble an hugeous rap with his stick,—and fetched a deep groan, and did not say so much as one word, and then led Miss Mary Ann out of the room—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: I'll tell you what, Bridget, it's all owing to his finding out the young gentleman's visits here to miss Mary Ann—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Yes, yes;—it stands to reason how it must be that—dear me! he locks poor miss Mary Ann up here for all the world like an horse in a pound, and I can't tell why or by reason whereof, not I—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: I'll tell you, Bridget—I understand these matters—he locks her up do you see, because as why he is troubled with jealousy—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: But how should that enter his head?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Oh! that pops into his head, because—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: What is jealousy pray, Peter?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p:
Dear heart, you are such another—jealousy, you may know, won't let a body sleep—it's for all the world, like so many rats behind the wainscot-,-I'll tell
you now by way of likeness—the gentleman you know gaved you a guinea—now putting case, any body was to come for to take away your guinea, do you see—that would put you in a passion would not it?—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Oh!—I understand it now—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p:
It's as like it as any thing—for see but here—Miss Mary Ann is his guinea—and you know when a body wants to be fingering another man's mo
ney, what does he do then?—why he brings you down to sizes an whole heap of London counsel, to quarrel about it, and abuse one another, and be together by the ears for ever so many hours—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: I remember all that, and it's as like miss Mary Ann as it can stare—but then I want to know why does not every body make the same fuss, and lock his wife up too?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Po! you fool! that's because every body does not love his wife as well as a guinea—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Then I understands the whole git of it—but law!—look ye there—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: It's master, as sure as a gun—how he looks, Bridget!—let us get out of his way—
The perfidious jade!—what a trick she has played me!—Oh! the little, treacherous—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Law! you look so strange, you are enough to frighten a body—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Mary Ann, I have seen Mr. Brumpton—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Have you?

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: He was wonderfully pleased with your letter—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: [smiling aside] By goles, I know why.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: What did you say to him?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Say to him!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Did you write what I bid you?
Altered it a little bit!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: A good deal, I fancy.
By gingo, I played you that trick—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: And was not it base, to deceive your guardian, who loves you dearly, and intends to make you his wedded wife?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: I could not find it in my heart to say the things you wanted me—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: And don't you consider what a crime it is!—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: It was only to play upon you—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: But such wicked letters, Mary Ann—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: It was you shewed me the way—how should I have thought of such a thing?

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
That stings, that galls— [aside.] But there are women, Mary Ann, who can write without be
ing bid—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: What, all out of their own heads!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Even so—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: And what do they write?

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: They make assignations; inform their gallants, when their husbands are to be from home;—they fix the time for amorous meetings, at routs and drums—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Routs and drums!—What be they?

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Wicked assemblies!—where women lose more than they can pay, and then pawn their persons together with the husband's honour, and so infamously pay off the debts they have contracted.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: And then do the men toy and play, and take 'em round the waist—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Ay!—then their point is gained—
That's comical enough.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: And then they fly wild about this town;—to the seducing gaieties of Vaux-hall and Ranelagh—

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Law! I never heard of those—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
Ranelagh, child, is a wicked round of sin, intrigue, and clandestine love; where crowds
gather together, stealing glances, exchanging letters, negotiating riotous pleasures—Vaux-hall is a very Paradise of forbidden fruits, where shady walks ex
clude the conscious day, and every blandishment of sense, musick, wine, and opportunity, conspire to waken the voluptuous passions.
And must not Mary Ann see those places?

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: No—never—never, Mary Ann—Here—here is the marriage act for you to read—all young girls ought to have it by heart—This will teach them how unnatural it is to fall in love without the consent of king, lords, and commons!

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! but I can't stay for their leave—thy are too great folks for me to think of!—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Take it up-stairs with you—It is a very edifying tract!—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Very well, I'll go— [as she is going.] I'll go and try if I can't write a letter out of my own head—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: When she has read the marriage act, she will have a proper sense of her duty. So Peter!—so Bridget!—walk in—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Now if I can tutor these to my mind—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: For the love of mercy, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: I'll never do so any more, master—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Come hither both—I am not angry—you are no strangers to the affection I bear Mary Ann—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: No, that's for sure—you love her as well as you do a guinea—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: How now, Malapert!

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: I am sure Peter said so—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: No—not I—for the varsal world!—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: What's the matter, Numskulls!—Listen to me—watch my house well;—and be sure you neve let any powdered fops put a foot over the threshold of my door—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Yes, Sir!

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: No, Sir!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: But the wily arts of young men;—Think of a gay embroidered coxcomb coming to you with a piteous look: "I languish for your mistress; I die in her absence; let me but see her, or else I have one foot in my grave already"—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p:
Be gone about your business, fellow, says I—this is no place for you—My young mistress de
sires no such trumpery.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Mighty well, Peter, it can't be better—But you, Mrs. Bridget, will take some compassion upon a poor dying swain—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Go farther a field, and set up the sign of the horns somewhere else—do—no admittance for you here—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Charming, Bridget, charming—you do it wonderfully—But then says he "I'll lie down in the street, and there breathe my last—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: And then I run up to the garret-window, and souce a bucket of water on his head—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
Excellent! excellent!—it will cool his passion for him—have a bucket of water always ready—Ha! ha! I should like to see him streaming like a river god in the street—I am delighted with you both—But then he comes with his damned be
witching gold—Here, Peter, to drink my health—Here Mrs. Bridget, to buy you some tea.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: We want none of your dross—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: No—not we—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: That's right—shove me—push me away.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p:
Go about your business, I say— both shov
ing him.

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p:
Money is the root of all evil both shov
ing him.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: As I could wish—that's right—never spare me—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: We hate you as we do a toad.

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: You vile ugly thing.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: We can't endure the sight of you—

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: You midnight owl! you griping, miserly, old—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: There, there, hold, hold—But here, says he, here's the money for you holding out money.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: I humbly thank your honour

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Villain! traitor! [strikes him.] Is this your virtue at last?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Law! what's the matter? was not I to take it?

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: What have I been labouring all this time?—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: But you did not shew the money at first—I could have refused it ever so long, if I had not seen the colour of it.—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: The way of the world—But you are never to take it—Money is the ruin of the world—It declares war,—it patches up a peace,—it makes lawyers speak,—it makes some folks hold their tongues,—Go, and think of all this—
Yes, Sir!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: And remember you have no business with money—Come, and shut the street-door after me.

sp.speaker: Bridget. Peter.
sp.p: Yes, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
I must pay a friendly visit to brother Old
castle—Ha! ha! I know things are going wrong with him—I must gratify my curiosity—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Brother Lovibond! I go on as I could wish—my family is all as exact as clock-work—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I am glad of it, for the last time I met you—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I beg your pardon,—but now, loll toll loll! I am completely happy.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: My dear old friend, I am glad I have met you—Oh! such plague! such vexation!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Mind him, brother Lovibond—you'll see what order my family is in—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I was at the house but a little while since, and—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: And no admittance, I warrant—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Oh! the damndest adventure—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
A bucket of water upon your head I rec
kon—ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
Not so bad as that—I got over the gar
den wall, and—the adventure is whimsical too—the servants immediately conducted me up stairs, and—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Conducted you up stairs!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—mind him brother Biddul—
Call me Oldcastle—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Come, come, listen to this—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
But, pox take it—my usual good fortune failed me—I was not in the room two minutes when old Stiff-rump came tottering up—no way for a retreat—I was obliged to skulk in a dark nook, where I was almost stifled—In he came, and the lovely an
gel immediately accosted him in such a tone of sim
plicity—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Simplicity—ha! ha!—well, well,—let us hear—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
The curmudgeon did not utter a syl
lable—walked about the room, fetched a deep groan,—banged the table with his cane,—took her by the arm,—and led her away with him—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! a narrow escape—brother Bid
dulph—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Call me Oldcastle, I say.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha! — Simplicity is an admirable preservative of young girls—Ha! ha! well, young gentlemen, and how did all this end?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: His back was no sooner turned, than I stole down stairs, tipt the servant a couple of guineas, and so got clear off.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
The old gentleman is going on delight
fully — his family is all like clock-work!—ha! ha! ha! — I have satisfied my curiosity — a good day to you.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: This is a mortal stroke!—Oh! Peter! Peter! Is this his virtue? — this his contempt of money!—this his bucket of water!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: What a crusty old Cent. per Cent. it is!

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Brumpton! — Well encountered—I have been in quest of you this hour.—This is the very crisis of your fate, man.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Hey! how! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: A train of gunpowder is laid, and there is Sir Theodore with a lighted match ready to blow you to the moon.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Explain, my dear boy, explain.

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p:
Why then, in plain English—your fa
ther has hired one of the good women who are skilled in the trade of leading young virgins aside:—She, by his directions, is to tempt the mistress of your heart abroad, and then to convey her out of the kingdom, where she will be lost to you for ever.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! it shan't be. — I'll watch the house day and night. Where's that scoundrel Brisk?

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p:
Poor fellow, it was from him I had this information; he is out of his wits about this busi
ness!—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Out of his wits! he is always out of the way.—Not a moment to be lost—I'll to my post directly.—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: My affairs are in a thriving way—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I am glad to hear it—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Success attend you.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
Oh! the devil! here's a piece of busi
ness.

div.stage: Enter Brisk, in Woman's Cloaths, with a Bundle under his Arm.
div.p: One push more, and then, Brisk, your toils are over—Come, that's the house.—As my master knows nothing of what I am about, I may have some chance to succeed here.—Now for a few superannuated matron-like airs— [knocks at the door.]—I found out her mantua-maker by good luck, and so now I know my cue—

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p:
Did you want any body, pray? No admit
tance here!

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Yes, truly, young man—La!—I am so jaded with walking—Oh! such a pain in my side—and my head! it perfectly swims again—I must in and rest a bit—I have brought your young lady's wedding-gown.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
How! is not that she?—Oh! the de
ceitful Machiavel in petticoats.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Why an you bring home her geers, that alters the case—walk in, Mrs.—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Ay! the little lady-bird will be as fine as an angel, I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Oh! the damned decoy-duck, there she goes sure enough—I'll wait for her in the street—'Sdeath! she may get her out of the back-door—I'll alarm the old fellow directly— [raps loudly.]—The old bawd shall be put in the stocks— [raps again.]—Fire, fire, fire! Master Biddulph—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: What's the matter there?—Who raps at my door in this—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Mr. Biddulph, Mr. Biddulph—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: What do you want?—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: You'll be robbed of your treasure, of all your heart holds dear — Miss Mary Ann will be stole from you—an old bawd will carry her off—she's in your house now—now—now—now—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: A bawd in my house? — I'll ferret her out, I warrant me—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Now, Sir Theodore, what becomes of your intrigue?—Bravo, Brumpton!—this is well managed.

div.stage: Enter Brisk, and Oldcastle beating him.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
Abominable procuress! — Horrible sor
ceress!—
Agent of darkness!—Minister of iniquity!

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Nay, good gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Vile seducer!—Detestable pandar!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Poacher of young game!—Kidnapper of innocence!

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: For heaven's sake!—I'm down o' my knees—have a little mercy!—

sp.speaker: Oldastle.
sp.p: Thou gipsy!—Thou witch of Endor!—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Get upon your broomstick and fly away to Lapland!—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: The devil's in the man, he will spoil all— [throwing off his woman's apparel.]—Nay, then, since you go to that—your servant, master!—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Confusion! what have I been doing?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p:
You have been in luck as well as I, mas
ter!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: A footman in petticoats all this time! Thou vile impostor!—Thou Newgate-bird. [beats him again.]

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Wounds! master Oldcastle all this time! nay, then I must pretend— [aside.]—How dare a servant of mine, rascal— [beats him.]

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Wounds! Sir, it was in your service.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Who gave you orders, villain!—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: That's right!—Who gave you orders!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: By what authority!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Produce your authority!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
To take such liberties with your mas
ter.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: I shall take the liberty to leave him for ever!— [runs off.]

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: This is delightful! this is charming! The villain will come no more—he has paid the piper!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: A scoundrel to behave in this manner! Oh, ho, ho! such an incident!— [in a fit of laughing.]—An unlucky dog I am—Poor Brisk, oh, ho!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Mr. Brumpton!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
Mr. Oldcastle! What, are you Mr. Bid
dulph all this time?

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: You see what plague and vexation you was bringing upon your friend—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: My dear sir, why did you not tell me at first!—If I had known that I was all this time trespassing upon your ground—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
You see what a scene of iniquity you have been engaged in!—But since you perceive
your error, I am pacified.—This discovery is lucky—it will make an end of all.—I'll tell you what, you shall come and explain your mistake to Mary Ann this moment.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: With the utmost pleasure, Sir, and wishing her all happiness, I will bid her farewel for ever.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: That will be right—you shall tell her that you repent, — that you now renounce all wicked projects, and are convinced it would be the ruin of her to marry you.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Lead the way, Sir; I am ready to obey your commands.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Very well! enough said—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
One dear interview!—Bravo! Brump
ton! you're in luck.
What do you say?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Only that—you'll make a fair report of me to Sir Theodore—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Ay! ay! that I'll do—come along—

div.stage: Enter Mary Ann in the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: La!—there's Mr. Brumpton with him—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: You baggage, what do you do there?—Get you in—Did not you hear the people cry fire?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Aye!—but they cry so many things in London, I did not mind that—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
Get you in, and never be seen in a bal
cony again!—It was there you saw her first, Mr. Brumpton;—ha! ha!—I'll have it taken down—Come along.

div.p: By goles this is pure—he is bringing him to see me—I have writ another letter since he has taught me that trick himself!—and now I'll give it him if I can—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
Mary Ann, I have brought the gentle
man with me.—He came to ask your pardon, and to tell you that he was going to be the ruin of you—Tell it to her yourself, Mr. Brumpton.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: I am sure I forgive him with all my heart, so I do.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Speak to her, Mr. Brumpton, speak to her—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Madam, I did not know what liberties I was taking with my friend,—and though my conduct was inspired by real love, and your resistless charms—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Pshaw! that's all preamble—to the point at once—You had a mind to ruin her, say so without mincing it—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
I must now renounce all farther pre
tensions,—since to adore you any longer would be a violation of friendship, and an injury to this worthy gentleman, who has been intimate with my father for fifty years—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: You may pass that by—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! he's a false man, and I don't love him—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
So that I most humbly beg your par
don—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Go on, go on—
sp.stage: he is seized with a fit of coughing.

sp.p: And though I shall never efface your loved idea from my mind—
sp.stage: he kisses his hand to her.

sp.p: You have my pardon, I told you so already.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Oh! lord! lord!
[recovering himself.] Well, have you told her you have done with her for ever?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Yes, I have got so far—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Very well! Now, Mary Ann, on your part, let him know your mind.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Must I say all out of my own head?

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Ay! ay! tell him all—I wish brother Lovibond was witness to this!

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: I am very glad you came to speak to me, Sir, and I understand you very well.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: But a little more at large—Tell him whom you chuse for an husband.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p:
Why, here are two lovers, for whom I have very different sentiments—I love one of them— [frowning at Oldcastle.]—and— [smiling at Brump
ton.]—I hate the other. The company of one is al
ways agreeable— [to Oldcastle sullenly.]—and— [smiling at Brumpton.]—I don't care if I never see the other's face.—I should like to be married to one of them— [to Oldcastle.]—and— [smiling to Brumpton.]—I had as soon be gibbetted, as be mar
ried to the other.—But my own Mr. Oldcastle— [toys and plays with him, then turning to Brumpton.]—I love you of all things.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: You have won my heart.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: But do you forgive I every thing now?—Ah! you don't love me. sings 'Go Naughty Man,' and reaches a letter to Brumpton.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I do—in troth I do—ha! ha! ha!—Mr. Brumpton, you see I have not suggested a word—all the dictates of her own heart—
All from the very bottom of my heart!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Since I understand you, Ma'am, I shall remove the hated object from your sight.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: The sooner the better.
sp.stage: then turns and plays with Oldcastle.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Mr. Oldcastle, I have the honour, Sir, to wish you all happiness.—And I fly this moment to put your commands in execution, Ma'am—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: You can't go about it too fast.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: You may rely upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: And don't let me be unhappy any more.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: You may depend upon me.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
So—so—now I'll attend you down.—Po!—no ceremony.—You have made me happy, Mr. Brumpton—you have made Mary Ann happy.—Come, I'll let you out, Mr. Brump
ton.
I attend you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: By goles, he has taught me a little wit himself; and if Mr. Brumpton follows my directions, I shall be pure and happy at last.

div.head: ACT V.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p:
HUSH!—don't speak so loud, you'll give the alarm else to my keepers be
low stairs, and all is ruin'd—I don't know what to say, Mr. Bellford;—my heart begins to fail me—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p:
But after surmounting every difficulty, now in this last stage of the business to let your spirits sink, would be such a falling off from the character you have supported this day;—a character that sur
passes all the heroines in romance, both for spirit and contrivance.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: The difficulties I had to encounter rouzed my spirits for a while, just as fits give us for the time, more than our natural strength;—but now the conflict's over, my resolution staggers, and I am at full leisure to feel the weakness of my condition—I can't go through it, Mr. Bellford, I can't indeed—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Nay, summon up your resolution—Our mutual vows, the happiness that waits us, every motive, a thousand things conspire, and call for all the constancy you are mistress of—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p:
But then to break through all the pro
prieties of conduct—all the decencies which my sex requires—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: In a case like yours, the means are just which save you from destruction—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I tremble for the event—I shan't be able to escape—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p:
Trust yourself to me, my love—'tis but an easy step out of the window down upon the leads, and then through the neighbouring house—the peo
ple
are in my interest—come, resume your cou
rage—you cannot doubt my honour—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: But the censure of the world—nay, your own opinion of me—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p:
The world will admire your spirit, and when 'tis known, that the old gentleman was your dupe, and carried on the plot himself, your inven
tion will be applauded every where—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Why, I can almost laugh at him even now— [hears Lovibond coming.] Deliver me!—what shall I do? undone!—detected!—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: This is the consequence of delaying too long—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p:
Run into this room;—make haste—dis
patch [shuts him in] and to make safe work— Puts the key in her pocket.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Harriet, I am never happy but in your company—the minutes move with leaden feet, when I am out of your presence—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: And yet, you ill-natured man!—you can contrive to be out more than half the day—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Chide me not;—you'll break my heart if you do—every frown on that face is a death-warrant, and every smile is benefit of clergy—come, come, brighten up into happiness and love.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: You know your power over me—you can do what you please with your own Harriet!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Can I?—you are too good.—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Where have you been all this time?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I have been—but you look pale—what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Occasioned by fretting at your absence—and that hideous man keeps me in a constant alarm—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
Don't waste a thought on him—he'll trouble you no more—tho', to do him justice, I be
lieve his intentions were honourable—poor devil!—
ha! ha! I fancy he loves you dearly—Well! but—poor brother Oldcastle!—your sister has so bam
boozled him—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: My sister!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: She has admitted a young gentleman to visit her—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: She could not be so wicked!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: The girl has not erred so much from an evil disposition, as from ignorance—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p:
A very small share of sense, Mr. Lovi
bond, will give sufficient intimations of our duty—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Very true—now the like of you, would not have done such a thing for the world!—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Not to be empress of the universe—The young men of this age are such a profligate race.—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: You are fit to instruct grey hairs—the young gentleman—one Mr. Brumpton—a wild fiery young spark—he was in the very house with her, and she hid him in the closet—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: In the closet! well! after that, I will never own her for my sister!—the wicked girl!—I am glad I have not visited her—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—poor man!—he never suspected any thing—had it been my case, I should have smoked it in a moment—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Without doubt!—there is no imposing upon you—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Oh! no—no such thing—ha! ha! I can see thro' a millstone—the eye of an eagle for a plot!—But come—come—it begins to grow late—come, let me hand you to your chamber, and then I'll lock you in safe from all harm till morning.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Heavens! what shall I do now? [aside] Hush!—let me say a word to you first—don't speak loud.—My sister is indeed much worse than you can conceive—I wish you would step and bring Mr. Oldcastle hither directly.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Now! what occasion can there be—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p:
She loves that Mr. Brumpton to distrac
tion, and has actually made her escape, to follow the vile man.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Made her escape!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p:
She is in that room now—I have lock
ed her in—such wicked schemes as she has in her head! She has told me all, and intends to marry this Mr. Brumpton: she has found out that she is of age, and says she will be made a fool of no longer!—there's a spirit for you!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: A spirit indeed!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: But I have secured her to prevent the disgrace, to ward off the ruin—and—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: That was considerate of you—let me go and talk to the young vixen.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: No—no—that will spoil all—I have pretended to connive at all this—But the most prudent step,—I have learned all my prudence, you know, from you—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ay! an apt scholar you have been!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p:
You are very good—but there is no time to be lost—I would have you bring Mr. Old
castle here directly, that he may find her in the very fact.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Very good!—and then I shall be able to do the poor man a service, and make a jest of him into the bargain!—Keep her safe;—don't let her out—this will so torment him!—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I am glad my sister has found a lover, and I hope she'll marry him with all my heart.—Is he gone? [listens at the door.] Ay! I hear him lock the street-door after him—and now I'll venture to unlock this door.

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Thou charming contriver!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Oh!—this new danger has given fresh vigour to my spirits.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: And now, my angel, we'll make sure of our happiness—come, trust yourself to my care—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: And yet—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
Nay,—no more doubts—our passage to the next house is without difficulty, and then li
berty is ours.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I never was better pleased in all my life—I burn with impatience to see him—ha! ha! I shall never be able to walk fast enough—ha! ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Well met! I wanted to see you.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Oh! I am now the happiest man on earth. My troubles with young Brumpton are all at an end, and Mary Ann is safe at home.—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ay! as he thinks, poor man! — ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: You may laugh, but I shall like to see your plan succeed as well—what a dupe you will prove at last!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: What a dupe you are now!—the bird is flown, man; Mary Ann has eloped—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! you make me laugh.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: How secure he is! ha! ha! he little dreams—I tell you she is gone—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Always absurd!
You are ruined, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—do you think I don't know better.

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Don't alarm yourself, my angel—this is my house—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Oh! I shall certainly faint—

sp.speaker: Brumpton
sp.p: My dear Bellford—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Heavens! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Don't be frightened, Ma'am—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: No—this is a friend of mine—well! Brumpton, the business!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
My dearest Bellford, this is the most critical moment of my life—I have bribed the ser
vants—carried her off—she is mine—mine for ever—will you give me a room in your house for this one night?—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Why this ceremony? you know you may command in my house—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: What noise is that?—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: That's Brumpton, I know his voice—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I am frightened to death.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: The door opens, walk in, ma'am, walk in—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Light the lady up stairs!—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Hush! Let us hear him—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: I am wild with love, with rapture, and success!—I have carried her fairly off, in triumph, my dear boy! She was locked up in a closet, but I broke open the door—

sp.speaker: Bellford
sp.p: I give you joy—but my own happiness calls—bring the lady as soon as you will—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: A thousand thanks, my dear Bellford—Victoria! the prize is mine.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Are you convinced now!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
I am thunderstruck—Robbery! Mur
der! I'll break open the door—Watchman, call a justice of peace—call Sir Theodore Brumpton—he lives just by—Mr. Oldcastle wants him—his son has robbed me—I'll alarm all the world! [raps at the door.] Robbery! shipwreck! destruc
tion! ruin!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—he feels it now, and I am not sorry for him—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I am mad, I shall go distracted;—I shall end my days in Bedlam— [Enter a servant.] I would fain speak a word here in the house.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir, my master is somewhat busy, and—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I am plundered—I must go in—oh! villain! villain!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—now will he see which can train up a young girl best.

div.stage: SCENE an Apartment in Bellford's House.
div.p: What's all this noise!— [listens at the door.]—Ay! I hear his voice—How could my booby let him in? But I have lodged her safe, and this sword shall maintain possession—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
Where is she?—Where is the unfortu
nate!—Restore her directly, restore her to her two guardians—We come to demand her of you.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Yes, we demand her, Sir—we know she is here—and therefore—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: My house is my castle, gentlemen, and nobody must offer—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I'll search your house—I'll get a general warrant—She is an heiress—a ward of the high court of Chancery—'tis a contempt; you'll be committed for it;—she is our property, in law and equity—I claim her, I demand her; and I will have her.

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p:
This is an unseasonable hour, gentle
men; to-morrow I shall be ready to answer your complaints; in the mean time, I must beg you will leave me in quiet possession of my own house.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: But we are her guardians, Sir—both her guardians—the girl is under age!—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p:
Mr. Lovibond, you are her guardian; and what then, Sir?—Both of ye scandalous betray
ers of your trust!-I know it all—each circumstance—You would impose upon her tender years, that you may infamously plunder that property which was confided to your care!—
There is a cloud gathering!—We shall both be brought to a strict account—I had better make up this matter, that I may enjoy my own Harriet in security—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: You have run away with an heiress, and by the law of the land—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: I have a right to her;—I know she is of age, Sir, and it is my fixed resolution to marry her; she has declared in my favour, and nothing shall be a bar to my happiness!
She is of age sure enough; how did he find that out?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Better make the best of a bad bargain— [aside.] — But let me understand you, Mr. Bellford;—do you intend to marry her yourself?

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: It is my peremptory resolution.—But all in honour, Sir—marriage articles, for the purpose of settling her whole fortune upon herself, are now drawing in the next room.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
I see what course I must take.—If he marries her, I shall live in peace.— [aside.]—Mr. Old
castle, the girl is of full age.—Let me say a word in your ear— [aside to him.]—consent to the marriage, and get a handsome allowance for the trouble and ex
pence of her education—That word makes me laugh—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I am distracted; what shall I do?— [aside.]—I thought young Brumpton was to marry her?

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: No Brumpton on earth shall rob me of her!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: The trouble, and the fondness with which we have reared her—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: He will allow for that—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I have long lov'd her—Can't you resign her now,—you will be the death of me else?

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
Think no more of her—she is not wor
thy of your regard. Mr. Bellford will behave like a gentleman in matters of account, and—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Prescribe your terms—I am ready to agree the matter this moment—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
A release for the interest of rents and pro
fits—a cool five thousand for extraordinary trouble, and for her music-master and her dancing-master—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: He was her only master himself—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Agreed!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
Close with him—close with him di
rectly—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I wish you would resign her to me—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p:
I will not defer my happiness beyond to
morrow morning!—My lawyer is in the next room; let him draw up a memorandum between us, and your conditions are granted.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: It shall be done—we will both sign—Come, don't hesitate.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I shall break my heart!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Po!—no hesitating,—come and finish the business!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle
sp.p: It is a terrible stroke!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Never stand debating—you have made the best of a bad bargain—lose no time— forcing him along.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: But, Mr. Bellford—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: We must resign her—we must give her up—Come along, man.

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: I attend you, gentlemen—I agree to your proposals.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Walk in, my angel; you are secure here.

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p:
Ha! Brumpton—I give you joy—I con
gratulate you too, ma'am—and—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: I thank you kindly, sir.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
And now, Bellford, thro' the perils of this day we have both at last attained our utmost wishes. I could be merry about it, but I must give my fellow Brisk some directions. I have such a story to tell you—ha! ha!—I shall be with you in an in
stant.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: La! what a pretty room here is!

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Your appearance tells me, ma'am, that my friend Brumpton has found a treasure.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p:
I am sure, I am fortunate in finding him—for I led such a life; you can't think how dis
mal!—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: The scene will now be changed, and the pleasures of life will court you on every side.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Oh! the little compound of treachery and fraud!

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p:
I was kept from morning to night mew
ed up at home, and he talked such a parcel of bug-bears to frighten a body—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Oh the traitress!

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: And he said if I looked at a sweet illegible ∣ing young gentleman, that I should be illegible , and devoured, and swallowed up!

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: An old blockhead!—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Yes, I thought as much—But I am sure I am obliged to Peter and Bridget for letting me out, and they shall come and live with me, so they shall—Do you know our Peter and Bridget?—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: They shall both be hanged.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p:
And my old guardian wanted to marry me himself, but— [laughs.]—he talked in such a
manner, and said such strange things—But— [laughs.]—the joke was, he taught me how to write letters, and I should never have thought of such a thing had he not put me in the head on't—And he is so old, and totters about so; and he calls me his lambkin; and bids me read the marriage act, and a heap of trum
pery.—An hideous, ugly, old scare crow!—La! there he is.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: I have signed, Mr. Bellford, and they wait for you.

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: I shall give you no delay, Sir.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
Thou serpent, whom I have warmed and cherished in my bosom!—you must sting your bene
factor at last, must you?—Did not I promise to mar
ry you?

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Yes, but by goles, I thank you for that tho'—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: And will you desert me for a stranger?
He's a sweet man!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Viper!—this is your simplicity, is it?—I, who loved you so—

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah!—but his love is more agreeable by half.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Well! now every thing is settled.—So, madam, you are there, are you?—ha! ha! Brother Oldcastle, I always told you how this would end—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: If she had minded my instructions—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha! Instructions!—You brought it all upon yourself—but 'tis better as it is—your head would have ached all the rest of your days—ha! ha! ha!—I am heartily glad of this—ha! ha!—Come, Mr. Bellford, I'll give her away—here, take your wife—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Wounds! I can't stand this—I'll not be a witness.

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: But you shall be a witness; you are a party concerned—you must come back.

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Since they have agreed the matter, Harriet shall make her appearance.

div.p: What does all this mean!—Sure it can't be sister Harriet he talks of.

sp.p: You must, you shall come back.

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Don't be frightened—you are the object of my heart, and they will give you away.

sp.stage:
[forcing in Oldcastle, without looking be
hind him.]
sp.p: You are a party to the agreement—you must see her given away.

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: Here's the lady. [leading her to Lovibond.]

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
Ay! ay! give me her hand— [without seeing her.]—you shall see the business done, Mr. Old
castle.—Here, here—wounds! what's all this?—Harriet!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Huzza!—a reprieve!

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: Ah! sister there—what have you been writing letters too! [goes up to her.] I be glad to see you—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: What does all this mean?—what brought you hither, Madam?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: My love for this gentleman. She takes Bellford by the hand.

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—she is his wife all this time—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I was not by any means worthy of you, Sir—and so I have transferred my affections where I think they will be placed to advantage!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I am ready to sink into the ground with amazement!—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
Loll, toll, loll!—brother Lovibond!—you brought it all upon yourself—ha! ha! ha!—
I pity and laugh at you—ha! ha! this is the educa
tion you have given her—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: I shall die upon the spot—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—I saw what it would all end in— [follows him about.] She would have been too young a wife for you, man—ha! ha!—I am heartily glad of it—here, here, I'll give her away—here Mr. Bellford, take your wife—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: I accept her at your hand—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: And I give you mine, with all my heart!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Now, who understands education?—Come, madam, come you home with me— taking hold of Mary Ann.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: Ah! but I can't do that, for I be married as well as you, sister — [runs over to her.] he carried me to a parson, and it was for all the world, like what you used to say [to Oldcastle] about love, honour, and obey—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: What do I hear?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
Oh! ho! ho!—what a day of adven
tures have I had! but fortune has at last crowned me with success—My good genius has attended me throughout—my sweet, my lovely bride!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Brumpton!—what a life you have led me!

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p:
Where is the graceless, the profli
gate, the abandoned!—So Sir! [to Brumpton.] why am I to be called out of my house on account of your midnight practices!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Oh! Sir Theodore, I am glad you are come—your son will be the death of me!—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: What does all this mean, Sir!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: That I am married to this lady, Sir—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: He has robbed me of her;—plundered me;—he will go to the gallows for it—she is an heiress!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
Well! this is some comfort—ha! ha! brother Oldcastle, we are both in the same predica
ment.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: An heiress say you?—George, give me your hand, since you have not thrown yourself away—and was it your ward all this time?

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Yes, Sir,—ha! ha! ha!—this is the lady whom he called a milliner's prentice—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—and that was his fetch to deceive me, was it?—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—you have managed it charmingly—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: You'll drive me mad all of you—

sp.speaker: Brumpton. Sir Theodore. Lovibond.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: This is pure comical;—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Oh! I shall never survive this!

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p:
Nay, no uneasiness, Mr. Old
castle.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: I fancy we need not think any more of Hampshire now. Sir Theodore!—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: What are you there, Brisk?—You have been a sad rogue.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: I have been working for the good of your family, Sir!—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: So you have; I forgive you all—George, I give you joy with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
You see, Sir, I have married a for
tune for the good of my children; and the lady's beauty I fancy won't offend you.

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p: No, I embrace her as my daughter.

sp.speaker: Mary Anne.
sp.p: Ah! you are very good, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Theodore.
sp.p:
Come, Mr. Oldcastle, never be de
jected—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Oh! I have lost a treasure—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Yet you must excuse me, Sir, when you recollect the letter the lady flung me out of the window!—

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: Flung him a letter!—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
And when you reflect, that you your
self brought me into her presence to receive this let
ter, in which she prays me to be her deliverer!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p:
Ha! ha! the contriver of his own mis
fortunes!—Gave her the opportunity himself—ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: And when you consider, Mr. Lovibond, that you brought me Harriet's messages, and delivered me this letter with your own hand!

sp.speaker: Lovibond.
sp.p: How is this!—

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p:
A declaration of my heart—I had no
body to carry it but you!—

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p:
The contriver of his own ruin! deliver
ed her letter himself! ha! ha! how well he knows the world!—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p: Bellford, give me your hand—and so we have been struggling hard for two sisters all this time!—

sp.speaker: Bellford.
sp.p: We have, and from henceforth shall live both friends and brothers!

sp.speaker: Oldcastle.
sp.p: Oh! Mary Ann!—you have deceived me, but I shall be glad to see you happy.

sp.speaker: Mary Ann.
sp.p: And I am sure, I shall be always glad to see you, if you live these three years to come—Here's your marriage act for you! Sister Harriet, la! I longed like any thing to see you—and I am glad we are both happy at last—

sp.speaker: Brumpton.
sp.p:
A right use made of this event, will be of general service to us all—To these gentlemen it may prove a School for Guardians, where they will
learn not to bring upon themselves the reproach of a dishonest, an amorous, and contemptible old age—We, Bellford, and these ladies, who are now em
barked on a voyage for life,—we cannot fail of happiness—

div.l: To youth sure rapture marriage ever brings,
When from esteem the happy union springs.
